00:26:15.090 --> 00:26:18.080
And it would go down the list until
if found one that was available

477
00:26:18.080 --> 00:26:19.440
in the system.

478
00:26:19.440 --> 00:26:23.010
And so what you could do is you could

479
00:26:23.010 --> 00:26:27.850
predict what was going to happen with your
design by having a little more control.

480
00:26:27.850 --> 00:26:32.730
So you would specify multiple parameters
and options that were available, and

481
00:26:32.730 --> 00:26:34.460
that is how you did your failsafe.

482
00:26:34.460 --> 00:26:38.950
And by default, once you've got all
the way to the end, if none of these were

483
00:26:38.950 --> 00:26:41.880
available it would just say find
the first serif font that's available and

484
00:26:41.880 --> 00:26:43.040
just use that.

485
00:26:43.040 --> 00:26:44.560
So that's what this is all about.

486
00:26:44.560 --> 00:26:48.495
So if I look through my list here, I keep
going down, I can see that there are some

487
00:26:48.495 --> 00:26:52.840
sans-serif options, so Gill Sans,
Gill Sans MT, Myriad Pro.

488
00:26:52.840 --> 00:26:56.660
So the good thing about the sans serif
fonts, is they literally have sans in

489
00:26:56.660 --> 00:26:59.930
the name sometimes, and
that tells you that it's sans serif.

490
00:26:59.930 --> 00:27:03.790
So in this example,
I would like to use a sans serif grouping.

491
00:27:03.790 --> 00:27:07.250
And I thinking that I'm gonna go
with this Gotham Helvetica Neue and

492
00:27:07.250 --> 00:27:09.360
Helvetica Ariel Sans-Serif.

493
00:27:09.360 --> 00:27:12.810
So again, it's gonna give me this group,
but if I wanted to, I could come here and

494
00:27:12.810 --> 00:27:14.980
manage my own font set.

495
00:27:14.980 --> 00:27:19.540
So if I click on this, I can now choose
from the Adobe web fonts, because,

496
00:27:19.540 --> 00:27:22.910
when you're using Dreamweaver CC, you're
connected to the Creative Cloud, and

497
00:27:22.910 --> 00:27:25.680
you have a whole bunch of font
sets that are available to you

498
00:27:25.680 --> 00:27:27.220
to download from the internet.

499
00:27:27.220 --> 00:27:30.600
Or I could do local web fonts that
are available to me and I could search for

500
00:27:30.600 --> 00:27:31.830
them and bring them in.

501
00:27:31.830 --> 00:27:36.160
So I could create my own set, or
I could have a stack here, and

502
00:27:36.160 --> 00:27:38.830
I could go edit the stacks
that are all ready available.

503
00:27:40.010 --> 00:27:43.480
Ok, so I hit the plus, that will add it,
or hit minus, it will subtract it.

504
00:27:43.480 --> 00:27:47.920
And I can build from the system fonts
that I have installed on my computer.

505
00:27:47.920 --> 00:27:52.110
And these are basically the windows system
fonts that come with Windows 7 in my case.

506
00:27:53.490 --> 00:27:55.890
So I don't want to change any of
those right now, but if I did,

507
00:27:55.890 --> 00:27:57.500
I could do that from here.

508
00:27:57.500 --> 00:28:02.340
What I did want to do is I wanted to
make sure that I chose the gothem

509
00:28:02.340 --> 00:28:04.100
arial sens serif.

510
00:28:04.100 --> 00:28:07.470
And when I do that,
notice the text now no longer has feet.

511
00:28:07.470 --> 00:28:09.520
So there are no longer flourishes.

512
00:28:09.520 --> 00:28:12.780
The point of serif versus sans serif is

513
00:28:12.780 --> 00:28:16.860
we're trying to make our designs
as user friendly as possible.

514
00:28:16.860 --> 00:28:20.359
And we're trying to make it so
that way we have readable text.

515
00:28:21.640 --> 00:28:26.000
Sans serif fonts are very readable,
serif fonts are a little harder to read,

516
00:28:26.000 --> 00:28:28.650
especially when the text is
small because they're very busy.

517
00:28:28.650 --> 00:28:30.270
So it's important to keep that in mind.

518
00:28:30.270 --> 00:28:33.600
If you're going to have large text,
you can use serif all day long.

519
00:28:33.600 --> 00:28:36.870
If you're going to have small
text like in articles, or

520
00:28:36.870 --> 00:28:40.960
in the body text of whatever messages
you're trying to pass on to your user,

521
00:28:40.960 --> 00:28:42.770
you're gonna want to
have sans serif fonts.

522
00:28:42.770 --> 00:28:44.760
And that's what I've chosen here.

523
00:28:44.760 --> 00:28:46.010
So let me set this back to white.

524
00:28:47.190 --> 00:28:48.870
So that's the font group, right?

525
00:28:48.870 --> 00:28:51.190
So I've got the font group,
I've changed the font family,

526
00:28:51.190 --> 00:28:53.370
and I've changed the color.

527
00:28:53.370 --> 00:28:55.230
Now the next icon is for borders.

528
00:28:55.230 --> 00:28:58.530
So if I wanted to add a border around
the body, then I could do that here.

529
00:28:58.530 --> 00:28:59.940
We're not ready for borders just yet, but

530
00:28:59.940 --> 00:29:01.550
I would like to change
the background colors.

531
00:29:01.550 --> 00:29:04.310
So as I stated,
I'm gonna add a background color.

532
00:29:04.310 --> 00:29:06.680
And right here I can choose
the background color option,

533
00:29:06.680 --> 00:29:10.910
I get the same color picker and
in this case, I just wanted to go black.

534
00:29:10.910 --> 00:29:13.730
So I'm gonna choose that, click off of it.

535
00:29:13.730 --> 00:29:17.680
Or maybe select it first,
add it as a swatch, and

536
00:29:17.680 --> 00:29:19.490
now click off of it, and there we go.

537
00:29:19.490 --> 00:29:21.390
So now I can actually read this text.

538
00:29:21.390 --> 00:29:28.130
So using cascading style sheets
of applied styles to the body tag

539
00:29:28.130 --> 00:29:32.820
of my code, and it's applying it
to all the content moving forward.

540
00:29:32.820 --> 00:29:35.710
So all my content moving forward,
no matter what content sections,

541
00:29:35.710 --> 00:29:40.950
no matter what articles, no matter
what text I import in, it will always

542
00:29:40.950 --> 00:29:45.550
be white Fonts with the Gotham
style on black background.

543
00:29:45.550 --> 00:29:48.850
>> Well, Jim, thank you, I do
appreciate you helping us out with CSS,

544
00:29:48.850 --> 00:29:50.980
not only defining what CSS is,

545
00:29:50.980 --> 00:29:56.360
but showing us around the Dreamweaver
interface and what we can do with that.

546
00:29:56.360 --> 00:30:00.200
I do see that we are coming to the end
of another wonderful episode here, so

547
00:30:00.200 --> 00:30:03.190
before we sign out do you
have any additional words?

548
00:30:03.190 --> 00:30:04.630
>> Sure, thank you, Wes.

549
00:30:04.630 --> 00:30:09.600
I just want you to keep in mind that I
didn't have to write any code for this.

550
00:30:09.600 --> 00:30:13.590
And again I would like to show you the
code that was written by the system and

551
00:30:13.590 --> 00:30:15.010
just talk about that for one minute.

552
00:30:15.010 --> 00:30:17.655
So I go back to code view here, and

553
00:30:17.655 --> 00:30:21.405
I look at the code that was written,
this is the section where I created it.

554
00:30:21.405 --> 00:30:25.535
Because the first thing I did over here to
the right was I chose to create a style

555
00:30:25.535 --> 00:30:30.030
inside embedded in my document, and
so I created the style tag, and

556
00:30:30.030 --> 00:30:32.900
here's the body tag that
it applied those styles to.

557
00:30:32.900 --> 00:30:35.890
And here's the color of the font, white.

558
00:30:35.890 --> 00:30:37.040
Here's the font family.

559
00:30:37.040 --> 00:30:38.860
There's the Gotham font.

560
00:30:38.860 --> 00:30:41.570
And here's the background color, black.

561
00:30:41.570 --> 00:30:42.550
So, there's all that code.

562
00:30:42.550 --> 00:30:44.120
And that's inside of a container.

563
00:30:44.120 --> 00:30:47.520
Now, one thing I do like about
CC Is if you hover over these and

564
00:30:47.520 --> 00:30:48.710
your not sure what the color is,

565
00:30:48.710 --> 00:30:52.220
it literally shows you a swatch of
what that color representation is.

566
00:30:52.220 --> 00:30:55.110
So if you aren't sure,
you'll get a representation.

567
00:30:55.110 --> 00:30:56.970
So very nice for them to do that.

568
00:30:56.970 --> 00:31:02.025
But this is the body tag And
these are the styles within my container.

569
00:31:02.025 --> 00:31:05.705
And the container here is contained
within these curly braces.

570
00:31:05.705 --> 00:31:09.255
>> Well we do appreciate that very good
information, and now thank you and

571
00:31:09.255 --> 00:31:13.167
I know that we got plenty more to come
here on Dreamweaver But we're gonna

572
00:31:13.167 --> 00:31:16.987
go ahead and have to save that for
another episode, so, thank you again, Jim.

573
00:31:16.987 --> 00:31:17.737
I do appreciate it.

574
00:31:17.737 --> 00:31:20.307
We do appreciate you, the viewers out
there, but we're gonna go ahead and

575
00:31:20.307 --> 00:31:21.777
sign out here at ITProTV.

576
00:31:21.777 --> 00:31:23.297
I've been your host, Wes Bryan.

577
00:31:23.297 --> 00:31:24.517
>> And I'm Jim Surrell.

578
00:31:24.517 --> 00:31:26.699
>> And we'll see you next time.

579
00:31:26.699 --> 00:31:32.230
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Jim discuss the characteristics of common images uses inside of websites today. They talk look at the Graphic Interchange Format, Joint Photographic Experts Group and the Portable Network Graphic file formats and their usages. They demonstrate how to insert an image within the website and the Assets Panel.
episodes.title: Inserting Images
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.995 --> 00:00:14.736
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.736 --> 00:00:16.421
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

4
00:00:16.421 --> 00:00:20.510
And in today's episode, we're moving
along in our DreamWeaver series.

5
00:00:20.510 --> 00:00:24.540
That's right, we're coming back with a
little bit more of the Creative Cloud 2015

6
00:00:24.540 --> 00:00:27.545
and joining me in the studios is
none other than Mr. Jim Searles.

7
00:00:27.545 --> 00:00:28.868
Jim, how are you doing today, sir?

8
00:00:28.868 --> 00:00:32.267
>> I'm doing great Wes, thank you for
having me again, and thank you to

9
00:00:32.267 --> 00:00:36.390
the ITProTV team for allowing me to
come back and talk about DreamWeaver.

10
00:00:36.390 --> 00:00:40.110
Today we're gonna discuss
inserting images into our design.

11
00:00:40.110 --> 00:00:45.500
So at this point we've got a layout and
we've created some content divisions.

12
00:00:45.500 --> 00:00:49.840
And now we wanna put some images inside of
these divisions to capture the audience's

13
00:00:49.840 --> 00:00:51.110
imagination.

14
00:00:51.110 --> 00:00:54.290
So to do that I'd like to
start by discussing that there

15
00:00:54.290 --> 00:00:59.480
are three types of images that
browsers recognize out on the web.

16
00:00:59.480 --> 00:01:04.350
And each one has its own
varied specification.

17
00:01:04.350 --> 00:01:07.920
And also has its own varied use.

18
00:01:07.920 --> 00:01:09.630
So for example, we'll start with GIF.

19
00:01:09.630 --> 00:01:10.820
GIF is G-I-F.

20
00:01:10.820 --> 00:01:13.070
Stands for Graphic Interchange Format.

21
00:01:13.070 --> 00:01:17.230
And this one is specifically used for
logos and

22
00:01:17.230 --> 00:01:19.630
anything with high contrasting colors.

23
00:01:19.630 --> 00:01:20.200
And the reason for

24
00:01:20.200 --> 00:01:25.890
this is because it only has 256 colors
that it can define within a GIF file.

25
00:01:25.890 --> 00:01:30.270
And specifically what happens
is when you create an image or

26
00:01:30.270 --> 00:01:33.790
some kind of vector graphic or
something with another tool,

27
00:01:33.790 --> 00:01:38.490
you bring out the GIF, it will look at
the most commonly used colors and say,

28
00:01:38.490 --> 00:01:42.370
okay here are the 256 of them and
these are what I'm going to use.

29
00:01:42.370 --> 00:01:45.780
So because of that,
GIF doesn't need to have compression.

30
00:01:45.780 --> 00:01:50.500
It reduces the file size by reducing the
amount of colors that are in your image.

31
00:01:50.500 --> 00:01:52.870
Now there are some benefits to using GIFs.

32
00:01:52.870 --> 00:01:57.500
And one of them is the fact that you can
use transparencies within the GIF file.

33
00:01:57.500 --> 00:02:00.260
But you also have the ability
to use animations.

34
00:02:00.260 --> 00:02:03.310
And you've all seen animated
GIFs out on the Internet.

35
00:02:03.310 --> 00:02:07.140
And you've seen the ability
to use those to make

36
00:02:07.140 --> 00:02:09.120
some funny captions within your design.

37
00:02:10.370 --> 00:02:14.250
The second file type
is the JPEG file type.

38
00:02:14.250 --> 00:02:17.830
The JPEG file type stands for
Joint Photographic Experts Group.

39
00:02:17.830 --> 00:02:23.820
And Joint Photographic Experts Group files
can contain up to 16.77 million colors.

40
00:02:23.820 --> 00:02:25.580
So they are 24 bit.

41
00:02:25.580 --> 00:02:30.050
The problem with JPEG is that it
doesn't allow for transparency.

42
00:02:31.070 --> 00:02:36.520
And at the same time it uses what's
known as a lossy compression scheme.

43
00:02:36.520 --> 00:02:38.258
Meaning that it discards pixels.

44
00:02:38.258 --> 00:02:39.909
The little dots that make up the image.

45
00:02:39.909 --> 00:02:43.369
It discards them in order
to reduce the file size.

46
00:02:43.369 --> 00:02:48.241
Also JPEGs were used out on
the Internet when the Internet was new,

47
00:02:48.241 --> 00:02:51.210
and because of that there was dial-up.

48
00:02:51.210 --> 00:02:56.200
And so very useful in a situation
where you might have low bandwidth or

49
00:02:56.200 --> 00:02:57.810
slow broadband.

50
00:02:57.810 --> 00:03:00.209
So that's what JPEG was all about.

51
00:03:01.830 --> 00:03:07.760
So, the next,
the third file type is the PNG file type.

52
00:03:07.760 --> 00:03:11.470
Now, the PNG file type was put together
by the World Wide Web consortium and

53
00:03:11.470 --> 00:03:13.580
this is a group that's responsible for

54
00:03:13.580 --> 00:03:17.490
standardizing the items that
are out there on the web.

55
00:03:17.490 --> 00:03:20.680
And it stands for
Portable Network Graphic and

56
00:03:20.680 --> 00:03:26.120
basically the PNG file type brings in
the best of both worlds in the sense that,

57
00:03:26.120 --> 00:03:29.320
it does allow for
transparency just like GIF.

58
00:03:29.320 --> 00:03:33.700
It has a lossless compression
scheme just like GIF

59
00:03:33.700 --> 00:03:36.960
in that it does not discard pixels so
you don't lose quality.

60
00:03:36.960 --> 00:03:43.120
And then the third thing it does
is that it allows transparency,

61
00:03:43.120 --> 00:03:47.940
lossless no compression, and
it does up to 48 bit color.

62
00:03:47.940 --> 00:03:49.520
I forgot what I was on.

63
00:03:49.520 --> 00:03:51.460
So, the 48 bit color is
the other piece there.

64
00:03:51.460 --> 00:03:56.270
So, not just 16.77 million colors but
many more colors than that.

65
00:03:56.270 --> 00:03:59.275
So, there is a benefit to
using the PNG file type.

66
00:03:59.275 --> 00:04:02.875
Now, you can still use
JPEG on your websites.

67
00:04:02.875 --> 00:04:06.563
And you'll see that they're
still out there en masse, but

68
00:04:06.563 --> 00:04:09.750
we're trying to move over to PNG for
the most part.

69
00:04:09.750 --> 00:04:14.270
We're trying to make that the most useful
type of file that's out on the Internet.

70
00:04:14.270 --> 00:04:16.900
>> You know, Jim,
one question that I do have and

71
00:04:16.900 --> 00:04:18.930
maybe you can help me
solve this riddle here,

72
00:04:18.930 --> 00:04:23.740
if it is one, is that JPEG seems to
have two different naming conventions.

73
00:04:23.740 --> 00:04:26.630
We have one with an e and
one without an e.

74
00:04:26.630 --> 00:04:28.220
Can you help us out with that?

75
00:04:28.220 --> 00:04:29.870
>> Yeah, that's a great question, Wes.

76
00:04:29.870 --> 00:04:31.182
What happens is this.

77
00:04:31.182 --> 00:04:35.910
Again, JPEG was developed when
the Internet was new, so back then,

78
00:04:35.910 --> 00:04:41.560
in the early 90s, mid-90s, we had servers,
or web browsers that couldn't

79
00:04:41.560 --> 00:04:46.470
recognize the naming convention that had
more than three characters after the dot.

80
00:04:46.470 --> 00:04:50.584
So basically we'd have index.htm
rather than index.html and

81
00:04:50.584 --> 00:04:53.410
that's the same thing with JPEG.

82
00:04:53.410 --> 00:04:58.692
JPEG, Joint Photographic Experts Group,
does contain the e in it.

83
00:04:58.692 --> 00:05:01.610
So nowadays we can have the four
characters after the dot.

84
00:05:01.610 --> 00:05:05.760
But again it was just
three that was allowed.

85
00:05:05.760 --> 00:05:09.897
So that's the whole point to the .jpg or
.jpeg,

86
00:05:09.897 --> 00:05:13.110
they're the same thing,
however, so good question.

87
00:05:14.240 --> 00:05:18.610
Okay, so with that said, I'd like to draw
our attention back to our application, and

88
00:05:18.610 --> 00:05:22.760
take a look at our design and
start inserting images into the design.

89
00:05:22.760 --> 00:05:27.730
So the first thing I'd like to do is I
would like to go in and define my site.

90
00:05:27.730 --> 00:05:29.050
I'd like to clean it up a little bit.

91
00:05:29.050 --> 00:05:30.970
I'm seeing a lot going on
here on the desktop and

92
00:05:30.970 --> 00:05:33.310
I would just want to point
to the Mysample site.

93
00:05:33.310 --> 00:05:37.210
Also at the same time, I wanna make
sure that my DreamWeaver application is

94
00:05:37.210 --> 00:05:40.410
pointing to the image
folder that I want to use.

95
00:05:40.410 --> 00:05:42.630
And make sure all my assets are together.

96
00:05:42.630 --> 00:05:47.450
So to do that I'm gonna go into my
site menu up here at the top, and

97
00:05:47.450 --> 00:05:49.080
I'm gonna choose manage sites.

98
00:05:49.080 --> 00:05:52.220
I could have as easily gone into
the files panel on the right and

99
00:05:52.220 --> 00:05:54.270
clicked on the pull down
where it says Mysample site.

100
00:05:54.270 --> 00:05:57.580
I could have chosen manage
sites down here at the bottom.

101
00:05:57.580 --> 00:05:59.380
So either way would be fine.

102
00:05:59.380 --> 00:06:01.030
It'll take me to the same location,

103
00:06:01.030 --> 00:06:04.420
where I can see I have multiple sites
here listed and as a matter of fact,

104
00:06:04.420 --> 00:06:07.820
if I don't want a site, I can select it
and hit the minus down here at the bottom.

105
00:06:07.820 --> 00:06:09.060
That'll remove it.

106
00:06:09.060 --> 00:06:12.500
But what I'd like to do with
the Mysamplesite is I'd like to edit it.

107
00:06:12.500 --> 00:06:16.880
I'd like to point it to the appropriate
location that I want for my files and

108
00:06:16.880 --> 00:06:19.680
then point it to the image
files that I need to use.

109
00:06:19.680 --> 00:06:25.090
So right next to the minus down here
at the bottom, I do have the pencil.

110
00:06:25.090 --> 00:06:28.630
The pencil means you're going to edit,
so I'm gonna click on edit and

111
00:06:28.630 --> 00:06:31.500
literally I get back to the original
screen that we had when we first

112
00:06:31.500 --> 00:06:33.450
created the My Sample Site.

113
00:06:33.450 --> 00:06:37.020
And you could see right now that
this is pointing to desktop folder.

114
00:06:37.020 --> 00:06:40.316
And I'd like to point that to the folder
I've created on the desktop called

115
00:06:40.316 --> 00:06:41.062
Mysample site.

116
00:06:41.062 --> 00:06:43.761
I'm going to look for
that in the list and here it is, so

117
00:06:43.761 --> 00:06:45.486
I'm going to select that folder.

118
00:06:45.486 --> 00:06:49.323
Now the second reason, and the real reason
I wanted to bring you into this dialogue

119
00:06:49.323 --> 00:06:51.895
box, was so
we could go to the advanced settings here.

120

00:13:03.931 --> 00:13:06.799

00:13:09.540 --> 00:13:13.870

00:13:13.870 --> 00:13:17.110

00:14:32.205 --> 00:14:36.770
What this will do is it will allow anyone

00:14:36.770 --> 00:14:41.195

00:14:41.195 --> 00:14:45.499

00:14:45.499 --> 00:14:50.660

it will not read anything.

00:14:50.660 --> 00:14:52.810

representation of what's going

262
00:14:52.810 --> 00:14:54.330

00:14:54.330 --> 00:14:58.300
Also, there is something

00:14:58.300 --> 00:15:03.770
Basically, 508C compliance means
that you have to have a way for

265
00:15:03.770 --> 00:15:07.410
people who are visually impaired
to hear what is on your site,

266
00:15:07.410 --> 00:15:09.438
to hear the content that's on your site.

267
00:15:09.438 --> 00:15:14.380
And so 508 compliance is useful
because it makes sure that governments

268
00:15:14.380 --> 00:15:19.390
follow the law, and that the Americans
with Disabilities Act kicks in,

269
00:15:19.390 --> 00:15:23.120
and makes sure everybody's doing what
they're supposed to do for accessibility.

270
00:15:23.120 --> 00:15:27.590
So by typing in alt text,
you've got a two-fold process here,

271
00:15:27.590 --> 00:15:30.560
you're benefiting in two ways.

272
00:15:30.560 --> 00:15:33.750
One, you're meeting the 508C compliance.

00:15:33.750 --> 00:15:38.999
But two, you're also making it so that
way your web crawlers for Google, Yahoo,

274
00:15:38.999 --> 00:15:44.172

be picking up this image and making sure

275
00:15:44.172 --> 00:15:49.227
that your accessibility is there, and
your rankings are gonna be staying up.

276
00:15:49.227 --> 00:15:52.227
So it's good for

A description of what this image is in

00:19:10.510 --> 00:19:12.180
But I'd like to add a new browser so

339
00:19:12.180 --> 00:19:14.049
I'm going to hit this plus
right here to add that in.

340
00:19:15.490 --> 00:19:19.180
And when I do that I get a dialog box
that says hey go find the file and

341
00:19:19.180 --> 00:19:20.040
give it a name and

342
00:19:20.040 --> 00:19:23.390
then decide if you're gonna make it
your primary or your secondary browser.

343
00:19:23.390 --> 00:19:26.480
I'm gonna browse out,
we're gonna search for Firefox.

344
00:19:26.480 --> 00:19:28.245
So at this point I think I have
to look for m for Mozilla.

345
00:19:31.319 --> 00:19:31.895
I think.

346
00:19:31.895 --> 00:19:33.723
Or something.

347
00:19:33.723 --> 00:19:35.031
Where are we?

348
00:19:35.031 --> 00:19:36.451
Let's see, I'm in my program files.

349
00:19:36.451 --> 00:19:39.785
And I've got Internet Explorer.

350
00:19:39.785 --> 00:19:43.435
I don't have Google Chrome here,
either, so

351
00:19:43.435 --> 00:19:46.725
that tells me I need to be somewhere else.

352
00:19:46.725 --> 00:19:47.225
Okay.

353
00:19:51.592 --> 00:19:53.292
And then, here.

354
00:19:53.292 --> 00:19:56.836
Probably here.

355
00:19:59.247 --> 00:20:00.640
Yep, there's Google.

356
00:20:00.640 --> 00:20:05.450
So, I just switched over to
the program files X86 folder.

357
00:20:05.450 --> 00:20:08.495
Now, if I scroll through this
list I might in the MC Mozilla.

358
00:20:10.393 --> 00:20:11.200
There it is.

359
00:20:11.200 --> 00:20:11.801
And there's Mozilla Firefox.

360
00:20:11.801 --> 00:20:17.130
So I click on that, open it up and
there's my Firefox executable file.

361
00:20:17.130 --> 00:20:18.252
So I'm gonna click okay or open.

362
00:20:18.252 --> 00:20:21.273
And now I really don't want
the dot .exe in the name, so

363
00:20:21.273 --> 00:20:25.280
I'm going to remove the .exe because
this is just a caption for the file.

364
00:20:25.280 --> 00:20:29.114
I might even want to put my capital
f's in there for Firefox and

365
00:20:29.114 --> 00:20:32.505
that kind of thing but
then it points to the location and

366
00:20:32.505 --> 00:20:37.298
I am gonna make this one my secondary
browser instead of Internet Explorer and

367
00:20:37.298 --> 00:20:40.911
the reason why I'm moving that
off of Internet Explorer,

368
00:20:40.911 --> 00:20:45.817
I should probably make Internet Explorer
my primary and it's built for that.

369
00:20:45.817 --> 00:20:49.430
Because over 800 million
people use Internet Explorer.

370
00:20:49.430 --> 00:20:51.260
They use some version
of Internet Explorer.

371
00:20:51.260 --> 00:20:55.799
As a matter of fact, there are still
versions of Internet Explorer from IE six,

372
00:20:55.799 --> 00:20:58.734
seven, eight, nine, ten and
now Edge out there.

373
00:20:58.734 --> 00:21:03.530
And so in some form somebody's
gonna be using Internet Explorer.

374
00:21:03.530 --> 00:21:08.226
The problem is with Internet Explorer
that it isn't standards compliant.

375
00:21:08.226 --> 00:21:13.216
For the longest time,
Microsoft was trying to be proprietary and

376
00:21:13.216 --> 00:21:17.401
so they didn't follow
the standards of the Internet.

377
00:21:17.401 --> 00:21:23.474
Up until about 9,
Internet Explorer supports up

378
00:21:23.474 --> 00:21:28.980
to 75% of the HTML5 and CSS3 standards.

379
00:21:28.980 --> 00:21:32.210
It's about 95% for Internet Explorer 10.

380
00:21:32.210 --> 00:21:36.140
And it's about it's I think a 100% for
Edge okay.

381
00:21:36.140 --> 00:21:39.430
So, we gotta keep that in mind
anything lower than eight

382
00:21:39.430 --> 00:21:41.570
is not gonna be standards complaints.

383
00:21:41.570 --> 00:21:44.970
And when we talk about responsive design
you're gonna see that were gonna bring in

384
00:21:44.970 --> 00:21:46.550
some files are going to make it.

385
00:21:46.550 --> 00:21:50.640
So, that way we can accommodate and
explore eight and lower.

386
00:21:50.640 --> 00:21:53.011
But, for now I've got my list
of browsers that available and

387
00:21:53.011 --> 00:21:55.537
I've chosen which one is my primary
which one I want secondary.

388
00:21:55.537 --> 00:21:58.641
And I'm going to say
that I need to save this,

389
00:21:58.641 --> 00:22:01.274
if I can see where my okay icon is here.

390
00:22:01.274 --> 00:22:04.210
I might not be able to get out of this and
save.

391
00:22:05.280 --> 00:22:08.267
My resolution's a little too high.

392
00:22:08.267 --> 00:22:13.230
Okay, I tried hitting enter.

393
00:22:18.920 --> 00:22:20.910
I'm scrolling through and
I think that's it.

394
00:22:20.910 --> 00:22:22.540
Nope, next one.

395
00:22:22.540 --> 00:22:24.480
There we go.
Okay, hopefully I saved.

396
00:22:24.480 --> 00:22:29.950
So now if I go down into, I was using
the tab key to cycle through each field.

397
00:22:29.950 --> 00:22:34.410
So this way I could find when it said
OK cuz I couldn't see it on the screen.

398
00:22:34.410 --> 00:22:37.060
All right, so I go back to here and
I should see that I have three.

399
00:22:37.060 --> 00:22:38.420
I have three options available.

400
00:22:38.420 --> 00:22:42.650
So if I choose preview in Google Chrome,
okay, it's gonna ask me to save,

401
00:22:42.650 --> 00:22:44.690
which is standard because
I made some changes.

402
00:22:44.690 --> 00:22:46.650
It needs to know what those changes are.

403
00:22:46.650 --> 00:22:54.120
And once it's done doing that, here's
what the webpage looks like so far, okay.

404
00:22:55.160 --> 00:22:59.380
Now, yesterday, I mentioned that when we
created our wrapper that our web page

405
00:22:59.380 --> 00:23:03.120
would always be centered if I did certain
things to the wrapper, and I'll talk about

406
00:23:03.120 --> 00:23:06.970
that in a later episode, but we're
gonna style that so it's always center.

407
00:23:06.970 --> 00:23:09.410
As I move my browser in and
out, I want it to be center.

408
00:23:09.410 --> 00:23:11.493
Right now,
it's hugging the left hand side, and

409
00:23:11.493 --> 00:23:14.531
that's good that the image was there,
cuz that told me that so awesome.

410
00:23:14.531 --> 00:23:19.030
Okay so at this point we have inserted an
image, we have several different methods

411
00:23:19.030 --> 00:23:22.742
to insert the image, we've used
the insert menu, on the menu bar,

412
00:23:22.742 --> 00:23:27.433
we've used the panel, and we've also shown
you that you can drag and drop images into

413
00:23:27.433 --> 00:23:31.930
your design which is probably the one that
you're wanna gonna use the most often,

414
00:23:31.930 --> 00:23:35.020
because you wanna be as
intuitive as possible.

415
00:23:35.020 --> 00:23:37.800
And that is there is no right or
wrong way.

416
00:23:37.800 --> 00:23:41.320
However, you should always consider

417
00:23:41.320 --> 00:23:45.035
using alt text when you
add an image to your site.

418
00:23:45.035 --> 00:23:48.625
You want to maintain 5O8C compliance,
you want to make sure that

419
00:23:48.625 --> 00:23:51.555
you're reaching to those people
who are visually impaired and

420
00:23:51.555 --> 00:23:54.485
have screen readers so
they can hear what the information is.

421
00:23:54.485 --> 00:23:57.805
So every image that you bring in,
no matter what it is,

422
00:23:57.805 --> 00:24:03.055
you want to make sure that you have
alt text in your properties panel.

423
00:24:03.055 --> 00:24:10.580
So click on the image itself and then go
into and select the alt text box, okay.

424
00:24:10.580 --> 00:24:11.140
Very important.

425
00:24:12.780 --> 00:24:16.060
And so
that is inserting images into your design.

426
00:24:16.060 --> 00:24:16.890
>> Very good.

427
00:24:16.890 --> 00:24:18.600
We appreciate all that information.

428
00:24:18.600 --> 00:24:21.320
It does look like we're coming to
the end of another episode though,

429
00:24:21.320 --> 00:24:24.039
but before we sign off,
Jim do you got any parting words?

430
00:24:25.060 --> 00:24:28.610
>> Yeah, just keep in mind that
when you're designing that

431
00:24:29.870 --> 00:24:32.470
you're gonna get a lot of
people coming to your site so

432
00:24:32.470 --> 00:24:34.790
you always wanna design to
the least common denominator.

433
00:24:34.790 --> 00:24:38.610
Meaning that somebody might
have a 12 inch monitor,

434
00:24:38.610 --> 00:24:41.420
they might not have
the best graphics card.

435
00:24:41.420 --> 00:24:45.240
So you might use JPG over
PNG because JPG has better,

436
00:24:46.480 --> 00:24:49.650
more compression where it really
makes your file sizes smaller.

437
00:24:49.650 --> 00:24:53.840
They might be coming to you from
a place that only has dialup or

438
00:24:53.840 --> 00:24:55.790
satellite connectivity.

439
00:24:55.790 --> 00:24:58.990
So, these are considerations you should
make when you're thinking about your

440
00:24:58.990 --> 00:25:03.100
website and thinking about putting
graphics or images on your website.

441
00:25:03.100 --> 00:25:07.100
And so those are the three
graphic types that you can use.

442
00:25:07.100 --> 00:25:10.880
The scalable retrographics are for
people who are going to use Illustrator or

443
00:25:10.880 --> 00:25:15.190
some kind of vector program to create
that, but other than that, PNG, JPEG, and

444
00:25:15.190 --> 00:25:17.180
GIF are the file types we're gonna use.

445
00:25:17.180 --> 00:25:21.710
>> Jim we do appreciate your expertise on
this information, and we appreciate you,

446
00:25:21.710 --> 00:25:24.280
the viewer out there, but we're gonna
ahead and take the time to sign out.

447
00:25:24.280 --> 00:25:27.130
Signing out for IT Pro TV,
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

448
00:25:27.130 --> 00:25:27.990
>> And I'm Jim Sorrels.

449
00:25:27.990 --> 00:25:29.182
>> And we'll see you next time.

450
00:25:29.182 --> 00:25:37.740
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Jim take a look at inserting links within the website. They discuss link types such as internal, external, incoming as well as their purpose when using them. They look at link concepts such as absolute paths, document-relative paths and site root-relative paths.
episodes.title: Inserting Links
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.384 --> 00:00:15.180
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.180 --> 00:00:16.540
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:16.540 --> 00:00:20.520
in today's episode we're moving
through our series on Dreamweaver.

5
00:00:20.520 --> 00:00:24.470
That's right, we're coming back with
more of the Creative Cloud 2015.

6
00:00:24.470 --> 00:00:27.640
Joining me back in the studios again
is none other than Mr. Jim Searles.

7
00:00:27.640 --> 00:00:29.000
Jim, how are you doing sir?

8
00:00:29.000 --> 00:00:30.760
>> I'm doing great again today, Mr. West.

9
00:00:30.760 --> 00:00:32.210
Thank you for having me back.

10
00:00:32.210 --> 00:00:35.150
And thank you for the ITProTV team for
inviting me to come back and

11
00:00:35.150 --> 00:00:39.200
talk to you about Dreamweaver and
specifically,

12
00:00:39.200 --> 00:00:44.440
this time we're gonna talking about
inserting links into your design.

13
00:00:44.440 --> 00:00:48.980
So previously we talked about images, and
right below the banner image that we've

14
00:00:48.980 --> 00:00:52.310
inserted we have a spot for
our navigation.

15
00:00:52.310 --> 00:00:53.900
In other previous episodes,

16
00:00:53.900 --> 00:00:57.660
we talked about the guidelines around
what you should have for navigation.

17
00:00:57.660 --> 00:01:01.980
But now I'd like to talk
about navigation and linking.

18
00:01:01.980 --> 00:01:05.360
So there are three types of links
that you have on your websites and

19
00:01:05.360 --> 00:01:09.970
those are internal links,
external links, and incoming links.

20
00:01:09.970 --> 00:01:14.870
So an internal link is basically a link
between webpages on your website.

21
00:01:14.870 --> 00:01:20.740
So when you go to and click on home or you
click on about us or you click on careers.

22
00:01:20.740 --> 00:01:25.095
Basically what that does is it take you
to a page on your website that gives that

23
00:01:25.095 --> 00:01:28.054
person the information
that they're looking for.

24
00:01:28.054 --> 00:01:30.661
So the navigation indicates
what that information is and

25
00:01:30.661 --> 00:01:33.130
then the page displays the detail.

26
00:01:33.130 --> 00:01:37.400
An external link is where you might
reference Facebook, or Twitter, or

27
00:01:37.400 --> 00:01:41.230
you might reference social
media of some kind, Instagram.

28
00:01:41.230 --> 00:01:43.960
So those are some options that you
would have available on your site.

29
00:01:43.960 --> 00:01:48.590
So you might have an image of the Facebook
icon, or an image of the Instagram icon.

30
00:01:48.590 --> 00:01:50.120
Somebody clicks on that it takes them out.

31
00:01:50.120 --> 00:01:51.820
That's an external link.

32
00:01:51.820 --> 00:01:54.880
Also, the last one is a incoming link.

33
00:01:54.880 --> 00:02:00.210
For ITProTv for example,
they might be advertising on Twit and

34
00:02:00.210 --> 00:02:04.440
so we end up getting a link from
Twit that comes in to your site.

35
00:02:04.440 --> 00:02:07.230
So those would be the incoming
links into your site.

36
00:02:07.230 --> 00:02:09.830
So, all of those are very
important to understand and

37
00:02:09.830 --> 00:02:12.840
to utilize while you're
designing your site.

38
00:02:12.840 --> 00:02:15.590
So at this point in time,
I'd like to go into our design and

39
00:02:15.590 --> 00:02:19.580
start working on our navigation
section and our division.

40
00:02:19.580 --> 00:02:24.000
So right underneath the image, where we
had our image for the banner that we added

41
00:02:24.000 --> 00:02:28.460
earlier, I'm going to click in here and
I'm going to delete the text that's here.

42
00:02:28.460 --> 00:02:31.700
This is pretty common to what we have
done before where we did the image.

43
00:02:31.700 --> 00:02:39.360
We removed the information and
it allowed us to do what we needed to do.

44
00:02:39.360 --> 00:02:43.340
In this case I'm going to put maybe
five words here in this section.

45
00:02:43.340 --> 00:02:47.758
And I'm going to convert them
into an unordered list, okay.

46
00:02:47.758 --> 00:02:51.670
So I'm gonna type in for example the word
home, because you always need a way for

47
00:02:51.670 --> 00:02:53.019
people to get back to your home page.

48
00:02:54.270 --> 00:02:57.790
And then I'm going to hit,
in the properties panel down here,

49
00:02:57.790 --> 00:03:00.420
I'm gonna hit the Bulleted List icon.

50
00:03:00.420 --> 00:03:02.220
Down here in the properties panel,

51
00:03:02.220 --> 00:03:06.950
I have this icon right here which
shows me text next to a bullet.

52
00:03:08.000 --> 00:03:12.526
It's between the text that shows
you one two three, Ordered list and

53
00:03:12.526 --> 00:03:13.784
the Italics icon.

54
00:03:13.784 --> 00:03:16.659
So I can click on this icon
right here on Ordered list and

55
00:03:16.659 --> 00:03:19.640
what it will do is it'll
bulletize that item.

56
00:03:19.640 --> 00:03:22.530
So instantly, I get a bullet next to home.

57
00:03:22.530 --> 00:03:25.450
So I want a new one, so I hit Enter and
I'm just adding bullets,

58
00:03:25.450 --> 00:03:28.070
just like I would inside of
a Word application at this point.

59
00:03:28.070 --> 00:03:28.820
So we've got Home,

60
00:03:28.820 --> 00:03:32.590
and then my next thought would
be like an About Us, hit Enter.

61
00:03:32.590 --> 00:03:40.320
And then, I would have maybe for
example, company information or news.

62
00:03:40.320 --> 00:03:43.179
We'll put company news out here,
hit Enter.

63
00:03:43.179 --> 00:03:46.373
And another one that we have that's often,
is if you're looking for

64
00:03:46.373 --> 00:03:47.650
careers with our company.

65
00:03:48.870 --> 00:03:52.500
And then the last one is usually a way for
your customer or

66
00:03:52.500 --> 00:03:56.730
the person visiting your site to contact
you, so we would have a Contact Us.

67
00:03:58.900 --> 00:04:01.250
So those would be the five or
so that I would use.

68
00:04:01.250 --> 00:04:05.530
Remember, we don't wanna have more than
seven, and notice none of my links in this

69
00:04:05.530 --> 00:04:09.070
navigation, none of them
are more than two words.

70
00:04:09.070 --> 00:04:11.310
Okay, so that's important to keep in mind.

71
00:04:11.310 --> 00:04:13.320
Now, you're probably looking at this and
saying, wait,

72
00:04:13.320 --> 00:04:18.680
these are stacked one on top of the other,
and how is it that this becomes a link,

73
00:04:18.680 --> 00:04:22.040
or a navigation bar underneath the banner.

74
00:04:22.040 --> 00:04:24.980
Well, we gotta use CSS
styling to change this up.

75
00:04:24.980 --> 00:04:27.490
And one of the things that we're gonna do,
is we're gonna make is so this list,

76
00:04:27.490 --> 00:04:29.800
this unordered list,
no longer has, as bullets.

77
00:04:29.800 --> 00:04:32.850
We're gonna make it so
that way they're gonna be side by side.

78
00:04:32.850 --> 00:04:36.600
And we're gonna change some things up
inside of the design of this list.

79
00:04:36.600 --> 00:04:39.920
So what I'd like to do is I'd
like to draw your attention

80
00:04:39.920 --> 00:04:45.330
onto this bar down here where I see Body,
Div, Wrapper, Nav and UL LI.

81
00:04:45.330 --> 00:04:48.240
This is known as our tag selector bar.

82
00:04:48.240 --> 00:04:53.840
The tag selected bar will show me what
HTML tags I'm currently sitting in.

83
00:04:53.840 --> 00:04:55.870
So wherever my cursor is
it shows me those tags.

84
00:04:55.870 --> 00:05:00.050
So if I click on the image for example,
now it's going to say body, div, wrapper,

85
00:05:00.050 --> 00:05:02.800
header, image,
because the image is inside the header.

86
00:05:02.800 --> 00:05:06.400
But if I click back in the text,
the text is inside the mav.

87
00:05:06.400 --> 00:05:08.120
And it's inside of an unordered list.

88
00:05:08.120 --> 00:05:09.730
UL is Unordered List.

89
00:05:09.730 --> 00:05:11.470
LI is a list item.

90
00:05:11.470 --> 00:05:15.650
Okay, so I can configure these
items by selecting these tags and

91
00:05:15.650 --> 00:05:18.930
I'd like to select, for example,
the UL, the Unordered List.

92
00:05:18.930 --> 00:05:21.030
Because I'd like to
turn off those bullets.

93
00:05:21.030 --> 00:05:22.240
Now, when I select the UL,

94
00:05:22.240 --> 00:05:26.050
instantly it selects all of the content
within that unordered list.

95
00:05:26.050 --> 00:05:30.160
Now, I'm going to go over here,
to my CSS designer panel, and

96
00:05:30.160 --> 00:05:35.630
I'm gonna click on that, and
I'm going to Insert a new selector.

97
00:05:35.630 --> 00:05:38.850
So just like we did the other day,
when we created the style for

98
00:05:38.850 --> 00:05:43.710
the body where we added black background
and white text I can come in here and

99
00:05:43.710 --> 00:05:46.410
add a style specific to this on our list.

100
00:05:46.410 --> 00:05:49.170
So I'm gonna click the plus here
in the selector section and

101
00:05:49.170 --> 00:05:54.050
it's gonna say okay this unordered
list is inside the wrapper,

102
00:05:54.050 --> 00:05:57.419
inside the navigation,
inside the unordered list.

103
00:05:58.630 --> 00:06:00.930
Now this is known as specificity.

104
00:06:00.930 --> 00:06:03.160
I'm being very specific.

105
00:06:03.160 --> 00:06:06.170
Now I could remove everything
to the left of UL.

106
00:06:06.170 --> 00:06:09.530
And I could effect every
unordered list on my page.

107
00:06:09.530 --> 00:06:13.830
But the problem with that might have
hyperlinks or links in my footer, for

108
00:06:13.830 --> 00:06:16.230
example, and then they're going
to get the same structure.

109
00:06:16.230 --> 00:06:19.140
I might not want that,
so by using specificity,

110
00:06:19.140 --> 00:06:23.680
I'm saying no, only affect the un ordered
list inside of the navigation bar.

111
00:06:23.680 --> 00:06:26.940
That means that only those items
