00:04:11.000 --> 00:04:12.660
is easy for them to access.

81
00:04:13.800 --> 00:04:16.350
Standardize the text format for
the webpage.

82
00:04:16.350 --> 00:04:22.530
Now, we talked about the two different
types of thoughts within design.

83
00:04:22.530 --> 00:04:25.920
Typography, we talk about serif fonts and
sans serif fonts.

84
00:04:25.920 --> 00:04:30.010
Well, designed to the least
common denominator,

85
00:04:30.010 --> 00:04:33.730
Serif fonts are always to
read if the text is small,

86
00:04:33.730 --> 00:04:37.820
Sans Serif fonts are always easy
to read when the text is small,

87
00:04:37.820 --> 00:04:42.090
Serif fonts are better to read when the
text is large, and they look more formal.

88
00:04:42.090 --> 00:04:44.470
So if you are going to be
creating a lawyer site,

89
00:04:44.470 --> 00:04:48.700
they do a lot of Time New Roman in their
forms and in their legal documents.

90
00:04:48.700 --> 00:04:51.330
So you might want to bring that
into the design of the website.

91
00:04:51.330 --> 00:04:54.730
But you want to use it sparingly, because
if people are going to have to read a lot

92
00:04:54.730 --> 00:04:57.630
of content on the site,
you might want to use a Sans Serif font.

93
00:04:57.630 --> 00:05:01.360
So even standardizing what types
of fonts that you're going to use,

94
00:05:01.360 --> 00:05:06.480
is it going to be Garamond, is it going to
be is it going to be, you know, Calibri?

95
00:05:06.480 --> 00:05:10.170
That makes sense, you're the one that
keep from one font to the next that every

96
00:05:10.170 --> 00:05:13.890
paragraph, that's going to make things
very confusing to the reader and

97
00:05:13.890 --> 00:05:15.620
it's going to distract them for no reason.

98
00:05:16.690 --> 00:05:20.120
And then lastly, provide support for
better user interactivity.

99
00:05:20.120 --> 00:05:24.720
So using contact forms to be able to
receive feedback, finding a way for

100
00:05:24.720 --> 00:05:26.625
the person to reach out to you.

101
00:05:26.625 --> 00:05:29.415
There is all this different
kinds of methodologies.

102
00:05:29.415 --> 00:05:33.275
Add your Facebook page to that,
add a link for Twitter so

103
00:05:33.275 --> 00:05:36.705
they can give you a feed and
add some content there.

104
00:05:36.705 --> 00:05:39.790
But you want to be able to
interact with the user in a way

105
00:05:39.790 --> 00:05:42.930
that they feel confident,
that they're going to get a response, and

106
00:05:42.930 --> 00:05:45.860
they feel comfortable providing
you that feedback and information.

107
00:05:48.590 --> 00:05:50.210
So, the target audience.

108
00:05:50.210 --> 00:05:53.780
One of the most important factors to be
clearly defined before designing a website

109
00:05:53.780 --> 00:05:54.710
is the target audience.

110
00:05:54.710 --> 00:05:58.720
This is primarily the group that
the site is to be designed to appeal to.

111
00:05:58.720 --> 00:06:00.610
So, can't stress that enough.

112
00:06:00.610 --> 00:06:02.220
Who is your target audience?

113
00:06:02.220 --> 00:06:03.740
It's going to drive the design,

114
00:06:03.740 --> 00:06:06.700
it is going to drive it in
ways that you didn't expect.

115
00:06:06.700 --> 00:06:10.090
For example,
we all know about Instagram, and

116
00:06:10.090 --> 00:06:14.400
Instagram is mainly
a mobile device platform.

117
00:06:14.400 --> 00:06:17.330
You can't access it on the web
if you're using a browser.

118
00:06:17.330 --> 00:06:20.000
As a matter of fact,
you go to the website, it says hey,

119
00:06:20.000 --> 00:06:21.930
click here to download our app.

120
00:06:21.930 --> 00:06:24.409
So they know that their target
audience is a mobile audience.

121
00:06:25.750 --> 00:06:28.490
But, you have audiences
that live in both worlds.

122
00:06:28.490 --> 00:06:31.440
If that's not your target audience,
then you want to be able to accommodate

123
00:06:31.440 --> 00:06:34.440
wherever they are and
you want to be able to reach them.

124
00:06:34.440 --> 00:06:38.240
We discussed gender,
we discussed different careers,

125
00:06:38.240 --> 00:06:41.930
we discussed people with different
skill sets of understanding, so

126
00:06:41.930 --> 00:06:43.680
you want to reach them on whatever level.

127
00:06:43.680 --> 00:06:48.290
A person going to Walmart is different
than a person going into a tech blog.

128
00:06:48.290 --> 00:06:52.840
And in the sense that they're looking for
different information, and

129
00:06:52.840 --> 00:06:55.395
you're reaching people that are not
necessarily techie on Walmart,

130
00:06:55.395 --> 00:06:58.920
whereas on the tech blog, they're
definitely going to have something,

131
00:06:58.920 --> 00:07:01.700
some kind of base knowledge,
and that's why they're there.

132
00:07:01.700 --> 00:07:04.110
They wouldn't have found the blog to
begin with if they didn't have some kind

133
00:07:04.110 --> 00:07:04.754
of tech knowledge.

134
00:07:07.166 --> 00:07:11.880
Also, the content on your site should
be relevant for the target audience.

135
00:07:11.880 --> 00:07:15.130
So we talked about
consistency within your text.

136
00:07:15.130 --> 00:07:16.590
If you're going to include audio,

137
00:07:16.590 --> 00:07:19.810
if you're going to include video or
any interactive elements.

138
00:07:19.810 --> 00:07:21.620
They should relate to
that target audience.

139
00:07:21.620 --> 00:07:25.700
So, see how the target audience
will drive the content and

140
00:07:25.700 --> 00:07:29.040
the design within your webpage,
very important.

141
00:07:29.040 --> 00:07:33.340
So think about those things when you're
looking at your target audience.

142
00:07:33.340 --> 00:07:36.770
Will they accept frilly fonts or

143
00:07:36.770 --> 00:07:41.930
colors that are going to be vibrant?

144
00:07:41.930 --> 00:07:46.370
Will they accept audio playing right
away when you get to the site?

145
00:07:46.370 --> 00:07:48.330
I will tell you that's one
of my biggest pet peeves.

146
00:07:48.330 --> 00:07:52.058
I was tempted to go turn off the audio
because it's glaring at me on a song I

147
00:07:52.058 --> 00:07:53.600
didn't really care to hear.

148
00:07:53.600 --> 00:07:54.564
Okay, the video, yeah.

149
00:07:54.564 --> 00:07:58.570
Should I reach people with video,
am I doing how to videos,

150
00:07:58.570 --> 00:08:02.990
am I doing A video to sample a product or
to demonstrate a product.

151
00:08:02.990 --> 00:08:05.970
Those are some interesting and
important pieces.

152
00:08:05.970 --> 00:08:08.620
And then interactive elements,
so how am I reaching them?

153
00:08:08.620 --> 00:08:10.440
How am I getting feedback from them?

154
00:08:10.440 --> 00:08:15.653
Am I offering them opportunities to
communicate with our organization?

155
00:08:18.589 --> 00:08:23.180
Design element considerations,
so we have to have balance, and

156
00:08:23.180 --> 00:08:27.020
we have to emphasis, and
we have to use color.

157
00:08:27.020 --> 00:08:31.390
So when we talk about balances,
you want to talk about symmetry.

158
00:08:31.390 --> 00:08:34.060
You want to talk about making
sure that it feels balanced.

159
00:08:34.060 --> 00:08:37.660
Earlier, in one of our previous episodes,
I took the site that we were working on

160
00:08:37.660 --> 00:08:40.540
and I made sure that no
matter how I resized my page,

161
00:08:40.540 --> 00:08:42.280
the content was always in the center.

162
00:08:42.280 --> 00:08:47.000
I made sure that when I added a table it
was in the center, or it gave some visual

163
00:08:47.000 --> 00:08:50.920
representation of being balanced in
some way, and that's very important.

164
00:08:50.920 --> 00:08:53.410
So your design should feel balanced.

165
00:08:53.410 --> 00:08:57.580
And you can kind of tell a website is not
balanced when you get to it and there's

166
00:08:57.580 --> 00:09:01.740
all this content on one side of the page,
but the rest of the page is blank.

167
00:09:01.740 --> 00:09:04.500
Now some sites do that on purpose for
emphasis, right?

168
00:09:04.500 --> 00:09:07.340
You can use these types of techniques for
emphasis.

169
00:09:07.340 --> 00:09:12.350
Because you might wanna emphasize,
maybe the advertisement on the right that

170
00:09:12.350 --> 00:09:18.670
is talking about purchasing tickets
to go to some theme park, okay?

171
00:09:18.670 --> 00:09:20.110
So you could do that.

172
00:09:20.110 --> 00:09:23.970
If that's your intent, then the balance is
the fact that you're now emphasizing that

173
00:09:23.970 --> 00:09:27.820
product, but you've gotta keep that
in mind when you're doing this.

174
00:09:27.820 --> 00:09:31.780
Now we talk about emphasis, you might want
to have some header ones on your webpage,

175
00:09:31.780 --> 00:09:35.700
you might wanna have something that draws
the reader's attention, a graphic or

176
00:09:35.700 --> 00:09:39.790
a video or something that brings them
to that article that you've written.

177
00:09:39.790 --> 00:09:41.770
And so emphasis is allowed.

178
00:09:41.770 --> 00:09:48.090
What you can't do, and it used to happen
in the old days, is have flashing text.

179
00:09:48.090 --> 00:09:50.160
First of all,
you're messing with accessibility,

180
00:09:50.160 --> 00:09:54.020
people might be prone to seizures and
they might have problems, okay?

181
00:09:54.020 --> 00:09:56.230
There are other ways to do that.

182
00:09:56.230 --> 00:09:58.160
Color could emphasize an item,

183
00:09:58.160 --> 00:10:00.940
you could highlight it with
a background color of some kind.

184
00:10:00.940 --> 00:10:04.340
You could make it so that way with the
reader, as they're looking at the design,

185
00:10:04.340 --> 00:10:07.520
maybe there are arrows pointing in that
direction or something that you've

186
00:10:07.520 --> 00:10:11.950
added to the design that literally
draws them down into that area and

187
00:10:11.950 --> 00:10:13.830
brings them to what you're emphasizing.

188
00:10:13.830 --> 00:10:16.030
So that's some design
element considerations.

189
00:10:16.030 --> 00:10:17.400
What do you want to emphasize?

190
00:10:17.400 --> 00:10:19.400
Where do you want the people to see?

191
00:10:19.400 --> 00:10:25.650
Have you noticed on the web, where is
the logo for companies usually placed?

192
00:10:27.230 --> 00:10:28.680
In the upper left-hand corner,

193
00:10:28.680 --> 00:10:32.910
because it's the first thing that
we as human beings in America read.

194
00:10:32.910 --> 00:10:36.050
We read left to right, and the upper
left-hand corner is where we start, and

195
00:10:36.050 --> 00:10:37.720
we move down the page.

196
00:10:37.720 --> 00:10:40.050
So the first thing you see is
the branding of the company, and

197
00:10:40.050 --> 00:10:41.530
that's what they're doing.

198
00:10:41.530 --> 00:10:44.210
They're figuring that out and
they're targeting that in your

199
00:10:44.210 --> 00:10:47.640
consciousness without even you
thinking about it, so that's emphasis.

200
00:10:47.640 --> 00:10:52.200
Color, I mentioned in previous
episodes that we bring color in,

201
00:10:52.200 --> 00:10:53.500
usually from the logo.

202
00:10:53.500 --> 00:10:57.460
So if somebody has designed a brand,
I wanna utilize that brand.

203
00:10:57.460 --> 00:10:59.940
They paid a lot of money to
make sure that the brand or

204
00:10:59.940 --> 00:11:03.920
they spent a lot of time with that
branding to make that happen.

205
00:11:03.920 --> 00:11:05.710
A lot of advertising goes into a brand.

206
00:11:05.710 --> 00:11:07.200
A lot goes on into that brand.

207
00:11:07.200 --> 00:11:11.030
So you wanna used that color scheme
that might be applicable to that brand.

208
00:11:11.030 --> 00:11:14.110
And you wanna make sure that the color
scheme that you use on the site

209
00:11:14.110 --> 00:11:17.490
matches that branding as well,
in whatever way it complements it.

210
00:11:17.490 --> 00:11:19.380
And make sure that it works well with it.

211
00:11:19.380 --> 00:11:22.170
You wouldn't use lime green, for example,

212
00:11:22.170 --> 00:11:27.270
if somebody is neutral
colors inside of their logo.

213
00:11:27.270 --> 00:11:29.750
It just wouldn't work.

214
00:11:29.750 --> 00:11:33.710
And the best examples that you can
think of when you think about color and

215
00:11:33.710 --> 00:11:36.970
branding, think about the major
organizations that are out there.

216
00:11:36.970 --> 00:11:41.290
IBM, I mean they've just got three
big capital letters, I, B, and M.

217
00:11:41.290 --> 00:11:44.840
Or Apple, just got the solid white
apple on a black background.

218
00:11:44.840 --> 00:11:48.620
Or Nike, you've got the swoosh,
or the swish icon.

219
00:11:48.620 --> 00:11:52.450
But the point is,
is they have thought about this a lot and

220
00:11:52.450 --> 00:11:56.560
they're gonna make sure that the design
on their sites match that branding.

221
00:11:56.560 --> 00:11:58.657
So color is important
when you come to this.

222
00:11:58.657 --> 00:12:03.617
And the three of these work together in
order to bring the entire elements of

223
00:12:03.617 --> 00:12:06.780
your page, and
make it feel balanced and work.

224
00:12:08.900 --> 00:12:13.820
So, we have some elements that we
can use to improve site usability.

225
00:12:13.820 --> 00:12:15.250
First of all, navigation.

226
00:12:15.250 --> 00:12:17.600
We talked about the fact that your
navigation should be clean and

227
00:12:17.600 --> 00:12:20.230
concise, it shouldn't
have a lot of clutter.

228
00:12:20.230 --> 00:12:22.690
No more than two words
in your navigation and

229
00:12:22.690 --> 00:12:25.979
there should be no more than seven
navigable items within your navigation.

230
00:12:27.160 --> 00:12:31.440
Use content that is clear and provides
visitors with the required information.

231
00:12:31.440 --> 00:12:35.290
People are coming to your site because
they want information about whatever it is

232
00:12:35.290 --> 00:12:36.110
you're talking about.

233
00:12:36.110 --> 00:12:38.370
It could be bird watching,
it could be surfing,

234
00:12:38.370 --> 00:12:41.230
it could be I don't know, anything.

235
00:12:41.230 --> 00:12:44.290
But whatever it is, you wanna make
sure that they get that information.

236
00:12:44.290 --> 00:12:48.660
And it's easy to find and easy to read and
clear and concise when they do get to it.

237
00:12:49.690 --> 00:12:53.540
Ensure that all text content is
checked for spelling and grammar.

238
00:12:53.540 --> 00:12:55.990
I can't tell you how much
this one's important.

239
00:12:55.990 --> 00:13:00.401
We gotta thank our content writers, our
copy writers, because they do a good job.

240
00:13:00.401 --> 00:13:04.030
But you've got to make sure that
everything matches the reading level of

241
00:13:04.030 --> 00:13:06.052
the group of people coming to your site,

242
00:13:06.052 --> 00:13:08.566
as well making sure
everything is spell checked.

243
00:13:08.566 --> 00:13:12.644
Dreamweaver provides spell check
capability within the application, so

244
00:13:12.644 --> 00:13:16.141
you could spell check whatever
documents you might link into and

245
00:13:16.141 --> 00:13:18.000
bring into your design.

246
00:13:18.000 --> 00:13:21.330
And I suggest you use it because even
though we think we might have spelled it

247
00:13:21.330 --> 00:13:23.310
correctly, you might have
missed one at some point and

248
00:13:23.310 --> 00:13:24.890
it's easy for us to do that.

249
00:13:24.890 --> 00:13:26.990
So, spell checking and
grammar is important.

250
00:13:28.190 --> 00:13:29.870
Use images that are relevant.

251
00:13:29.870 --> 00:13:32.190
So, if I have a bird watching site,

252
00:13:32.190 --> 00:13:37.170
I'm not going to put speed cars or
racing cars on my site.

253
00:13:37.170 --> 00:13:39.110
Unless of course,
it's part of the advertising, but

254
00:13:39.110 --> 00:13:41.090
then you're not hitting
my target audience.

255
00:13:41.090 --> 00:13:43.880
My target audience is bird watching,
so I might need binoculars,

256
00:13:43.880 --> 00:13:46.800
I might need cameras,
I might need sunhats,

257
00:13:46.800 --> 00:13:50.830
I might need that equipment that I
would take out to go do bird watching.

258
00:13:50.830 --> 00:13:55.240
I wouldn't necessarily want to talk
about speeding cars or racing cars or

259
00:13:55.240 --> 00:13:55.790
that kind of thing.

260
00:13:55.790 --> 00:13:58.590
As a matter of fact, you can tell I don't
even know what the heck I'm talking about.

261
00:13:58.590 --> 00:14:01.730
But the point here is, is that you
want to make sure that the content is

262
00:14:01.730 --> 00:14:05.690
relevant to your audience and in some
way is going to provide them value.

263
00:14:05.690 --> 00:14:08.401
So it's always gonna have
some value of some kind.

264
00:14:08.401 --> 00:14:11.380
We want to keep the layout and
the color consistent.

265
00:14:11.380 --> 00:14:14.160
So again, coming back to
the whole point of the logo,

266
00:14:14.160 --> 00:14:16.500
we want things to be
consistent within the design.

267
00:14:16.500 --> 00:14:19.440
And you don't want to jump
from one to the next.

268
00:14:19.440 --> 00:14:23.260
So for example,
let's say I am on my homepage and

269
00:14:23.260 --> 00:14:26.490
my background is a melon color orange.

270
00:14:26.490 --> 00:14:31.400
And I go to the About Us page and
all of a sudden I got fuschia everywhere.

271
00:14:31.400 --> 00:14:34.210
That might be jarring to the user and
they might be like,

272
00:14:34.210 --> 00:14:37.600
well, did I just leave the website
I was on and enter something new?

273
00:14:37.600 --> 00:14:38.960
So you got to keep that in mind.

274
00:14:38.960 --> 00:14:41.639
It needs to be consistent across pages.

275
00:14:42.690 --> 00:14:46.950
Provide options for users to search.

276
00:14:46.950 --> 00:14:47.720
So basically,

277
00:14:47.720 --> 00:14:52.960
the good thing about HTML5 is that one of
the form controls that it provides us, and

278
00:14:52.960 --> 00:14:57.290
we discussed this in a previous episode,
is that it provides you a search option.

279
00:14:57.290 --> 00:15:01.050
And you can put that anywhere in your
design, usually it's at the top,

280
00:15:01.050 --> 00:15:02.940
where people can find it,
and they can type in and

281
00:15:02.940 --> 00:15:05.050
instantly get to that
information they're looking for.

282
00:15:05.050 --> 00:15:08.580
Especially if you're running a blog site
or something that's going to provide

283
00:15:08.580 --> 00:15:11.490
articles of information, so
they want to get to that real quick.

284
00:15:12.750 --> 00:15:16.940
Allow for feedback, Contact Us page,
very useful for that kind of thing.

285
00:15:16.940 --> 00:15:21.019
So you can grab the information from
the user and maybe improve your design or

286
00:15:21.019 --> 00:15:24.971
improve the content that you have
available to those users that are trying

287
00:15:24.971 --> 00:15:25.624
to find it.

288
00:15:25.624 --> 00:15:29.377
And can't stress this
last bullet item enough.

289
00:15:29.377 --> 00:15:32.508
Test before launching, okay?

290
00:15:32.508 --> 00:15:37.448
We've talked in previous episodes that you
should have as many browsers installed in

291
00:15:37.448 --> 00:15:41.979
your development environment as possible
because you should test them across

292
00:15:41.979 --> 00:15:46.852
those browsers to see the differences,
to find the nuances, to change the colors,

293
00:15:46.852 --> 00:15:51.243
to change the design, and make sure
that it meets what you're expecting for

294
00:15:51.243 --> 00:15:52.238
the user to see.

295
00:15:52.238 --> 00:15:55.832
And only by testing will you be
able to determine what's going on.

296
00:15:55.832 --> 00:15:59.163
And I'm not just saying you should test,
I'm saying that you should go to your

297
00:15:59.163 --> 00:16:01.550
friends and say, look,
I'm working on this webpage.

298
00:16:01.550 --> 00:16:02.790
Can you test it for me?

299
00:16:02.790 --> 00:16:03.520
I'm doing this.

300
00:16:03.520 --> 00:16:04.540
Can you test it for me?

301
00:16:04.540 --> 00:16:07.440
Ask people, strangers,
find somebody in the mall.

302
00:16:07.440 --> 00:16:09.240
Say, look, I'm testing this site.

303
00:16:09.240 --> 00:16:11.050
Can you give me feedback?

304
00:16:11.050 --> 00:16:12.240
Do whatever it takes, but

305
00:16:12.240 --> 00:16:16.560
get the feedback to make sure that you're
reaching an audience that is diverse and

306
00:16:16.560 --> 00:16:19.510
they're gonna give you honest
feedback cuz that's important.

307
00:16:19.510 --> 00:16:21.273
Your friends are gonna say,
yeah, it's great.

308
00:16:21.273 --> 00:16:22.133
We love it.

309
00:16:22.133 --> 00:16:24.370
They're not gonna give
you that honest feedback.

310
00:16:24.370 --> 00:16:30.590
I had created this site one time, where I
gave it to a random stranger and she came

311
00:16:30.590 --> 00:16:35.670
back with tons of feedback that I never
heard from my close friends or coworkers.

312
00:16:35.670 --> 00:16:38.270
And I thought it was
the greatest thing in the world.

313
00:16:38.270 --> 00:16:41.000
Now, it technically was pretty good.

314
00:16:41.000 --> 00:16:43.230
But it still had some things
that were lacking, and

315
00:16:43.230 --> 00:16:45.950
from a perspective that
I'd never seen before.

316
00:16:45.950 --> 00:16:47.000
So it's really good for

317
00:16:47.000 --> 00:16:50.580
you to get that perspective so
you can start to be a better designer.

318
00:16:50.580 --> 00:16:56.240
And never be afraid of criticism, or
positive or negative information.

319
00:16:56.240 --> 00:16:57.620
Never be afraid.

320
00:16:57.620 --> 00:17:00.190
No matter what that information
is gonna make you better.

321
00:17:00.190 --> 00:17:03.110
Especially if you're
open to listening to it.

322
00:17:03.110 --> 00:17:06.670
We hear those horror stories all the time
where somebody writes something on Yelp

323
00:17:06.670 --> 00:17:08.080
about a particular restaurant.

324
00:17:08.080 --> 00:17:10.880
And then the manager of the restaurant
gets into an arguing match with

325
00:17:10.880 --> 00:17:14.990
the client in saying look this is what
we did and you didn't appreciate it.

326
00:17:14.990 --> 00:17:16.090
No, don't do that.

327
00:17:16.090 --> 00:17:18.300
Say, we thank you for
the information you provided.

328
00:17:18.300 --> 00:17:20.650
We're sorry you didn't
have a good experience and

329
00:17:20.650 --> 00:17:22.310
here's what we can do to make it better.

330
00:17:22.310 --> 00:17:23.760
And here's what we've
done to make it better.

331
00:17:23.760 --> 00:17:24.860
That's it.

332
00:17:24.860 --> 00:17:28.070
Take the information,
utilize it whatever way you need to.

333
00:17:28.070 --> 00:17:31.360
But certainly, take it as it is.

334
00:17:31.360 --> 00:17:33.850
Take it as somebody providing you
a way to make yourself better.

335
00:17:35.970 --> 00:17:38.640
So, now we're gonna talk
about layout symmetry.

336
00:17:38.640 --> 00:17:41.440
So, we talked about the fact
that you need to have balance.

337
00:17:41.440 --> 00:17:46.390
We talked about the fact that you wanna
make your design work for everyone and so

338
00:17:46.390 --> 00:17:49.860
here we're looking at some concepts
about the symmetry of your site and

339
00:17:49.860 --> 00:17:51.490
how you can find that balance.

340
00:17:51.490 --> 00:17:55.750
So horizontal symmetry we have
items that are side by side so

341
00:17:55.750 --> 00:17:59.170
if you got top down symmetry you
might have the banner at the top and

342
00:17:59.170 --> 00:18:00.790
the footer at the bottom
that kind of thing.

343
00:18:00.790 --> 00:18:04.630
There is symmetry that way as well so
that would be your vertical symmetry.

344
00:18:04.630 --> 00:18:09.149
But you can also go left and right as well
so I might have articles on the left hand

345
00:18:09.149 --> 00:18:13.464
side and I might have links to archived
articles on the right hand side, and

346
00:18:13.464 --> 00:18:16.430
that would be more like of a blog post or
something.

347
00:18:16.430 --> 00:18:18.969
Diagonal symmetry, so
this is where you're placing item so

348
00:18:18.969 --> 00:18:21.318
you might have a picture here
with some text on the left.

349
00:18:21.318 --> 00:18:24.400
And you might have text on the right here,
but the picture's on the left.

350
00:18:24.400 --> 00:18:26.380
So diagonal symmetry provides that.

351
00:18:26.380 --> 00:18:28.160
So you're breaking it up with images and

352
00:18:28.160 --> 00:18:30.920
you're breaking it up with text
in those opposite corners.

353
00:18:32.130 --> 00:18:35.830
Radial symmetry, so you're laying
out items in a circular fashion, so

354
00:18:35.830 --> 00:18:38.990
you've got objects on your page
in a certain way that, again,

355
00:18:38.990 --> 00:18:41.960
it feels balanced because of
that symmetry that's going on.

356
00:18:43.050 --> 00:18:45.840
Now, you might even have
asymmetric symmetry,

357
00:18:45.840 --> 00:18:48.250
I know that sounds like a oxymoron.

358
00:18:48.250 --> 00:18:52.540
How can something be asymmetric but
also be symmetrical at the same time?

359
00:18:52.540 --> 00:18:56.500
Well, the balance lies in maybe
the similarity of what's going on.

360
00:18:56.500 --> 00:18:59.690
Here, there showing us a large
object in the upper left, and

361
00:18:59.690 --> 00:19:04.310
the smaller object on the lower right, but
it might still feel balanced depending on

362
00:19:04.310 --> 00:19:08.050
what other content you might add, or
how you've presented the information.

363
00:19:08.050 --> 00:19:12.460
So, there are ways to get around that,
but here's the thing.

364
00:19:12.460 --> 00:19:16.700
If you look at information and
you don't feel good about it,

365
00:19:16.700 --> 00:19:20.320
if you don't get a good feeling, then
there's something wrong with the design.

366
00:19:20.320 --> 00:19:22.700
And use that gut instinct
to figure that out.

367
00:19:22.700 --> 00:19:25.750
And if you don't have that gut instinct,
ask somebody else.

368
00:19:25.750 --> 00:19:27.610
Always get a second, a third, a fourth,

369
00:19:27.610 --> 00:19:30.840
a fiftieth opinion, because they're
gonna provide you that feedback and say,

370
00:19:30.840 --> 00:19:34.720
well this design doesn't work for
me or it works great but

371
00:19:34.720 --> 00:19:38.450
only when I'm doing this or when I'm
in this browser or that kind of thing.

372
00:19:38.450 --> 00:19:41.019
And that's really important
to figure all that out.

373
00:19:42.657 --> 00:19:45.779
Now that we've talked
about design principles,

374
00:19:45.779 --> 00:19:50.400
here is one of the most important
pieces with regards to this discussion.

375
00:19:50.400 --> 00:19:53.280
And we're talking about copyright.

376
00:19:53.280 --> 00:19:56.085
Now, for those of you who are listening,

377
00:19:56.085 --> 00:20:00.645
it's important to understand that
anything on the Internet is not free.

378
00:20:00.645 --> 00:20:05.075
Just because it's out there and they tell
you you can download it, it's not free.

379
00:20:05.075 --> 00:20:08.982
There's gonna be something attached
to that, nothing is ever free.

380
00:20:08.982 --> 00:20:10.092
Nothing.

381
00:20:10.092 --> 00:20:11.702
So just keep that in mind.

382
00:20:11.702 --> 00:20:14.812
If that game you downloaded,
it was free, and

383
00:20:14.812 --> 00:20:17.517
you didn't download it from
a reputable source, it wasn't free.

384
00:20:17.517 --> 00:20:19.189
Somebody did something that
they shouldn't be doing.

385
00:20:20.480 --> 00:20:21.620
All right so,

386
00:20:21.620 --> 00:20:26.600
copyright is basically the act of congress
that give exclusive rights reproduce,

387
00:20:26.600 --> 00:20:31.990
distribute, perform or display the work
they give it to the content creator.

388
00:20:31.990 --> 00:20:35.610
Only the content creator
has this exclusive rights.

389
00:20:35.610 --> 00:20:38.100
If you can say that you
created this content

390
00:20:38.100 --> 00:20:40.110
then you can have those
exclusive rights as well.

391
00:20:40.110 --> 00:20:42.020
If you can't say that,

392
00:20:42.020 --> 00:20:46.540
then you do not have anything to do with
this Digital Millennium Copyrights Act.

393
00:20:46.540 --> 00:20:49.040
It's not protecting you in any way.

394
00:20:49.040 --> 00:20:52.300
If you find an image on the Internet and
you wanna pull it down and use it so

395
00:20:52.300 --> 00:20:56.130
you can make money,
you have just violated a law.

396
00:20:56.130 --> 00:20:59.710
If you rent and you found that movie on
the Internet and you downloaded it and

397
00:20:59.710 --> 00:21:02.930
you started watching it,
you have just violated the law,

398
00:21:02.930 --> 00:21:06.370
unless you either paid for it or you have
a subscription or it's on Netflix or

399
00:21:06.370 --> 00:21:07.700
some other subscription service.

400
00:21:09.450 --> 00:21:11.230
Video, especially.

401
00:21:11.230 --> 00:21:13.607
Video content, unless it's on YouTube.

402
00:21:13.607 --> 00:21:16.069
And even then it might
still be an infringement.

403
00:21:16.069 --> 00:21:19.858
The point here is, you might not be
infringing, but somebody else might.

404
00:21:19.858 --> 00:21:23.060
So we gotta keep in mind that there
are copyrights out there to protect

405
00:21:23.060 --> 00:21:26.120
the content creators of
their intellectual property.

406
00:21:27.670 --> 00:21:29.500
So what is copyrightable work?

407
00:21:29.500 --> 00:21:33.700
Copyrightable work is anything you create.

408
00:21:33.700 --> 00:21:35.990
Anything you create.

409
00:21:35.990 --> 00:21:40.520
However, if you derive your creation from
somebody else, you didn't create it.

410
00:21:40.520 --> 00:21:41.590
It's called a derivative work.

411
00:21:42.740 --> 00:21:44.530
So you have to think about it.

412
00:21:44.530 --> 00:21:49.320
And create it from your own mind and
from your own experience and

413
00:21:49.320 --> 00:21:51.090
from your own skill set.

414
00:21:51.090 --> 00:21:54.160
It has to be created by you,
that is copyrightable work.

415
00:21:55.210 --> 00:21:58.720
You become the author and you become
protected by that act of congress.

416
00:21:58.720 --> 00:22:00.500
The Digital Millennium Copyright Act.

417
00:22:02.980 --> 00:22:06.860
Derivative work, and
I'll tell you the most famous case.

418
00:22:06.860 --> 00:22:07.990
When Obama was running for

419
00:22:07.990 --> 00:22:12.250
President, a poster appeared with
the word hope underneath it.

420
00:22:12.250 --> 00:22:15.540
And it had Obama looking off into
the distance, and one side was red,

421
00:22:15.540 --> 00:22:17.960
one side was blue, and
it was opposite on his face.

422
00:22:19.120 --> 00:22:23.700
And this became an incredibly
popular visual to represent

423
00:22:23.700 --> 00:22:27.240
the campaign to represent
everything that was going on.

424
00:22:27.240 --> 00:22:32.340
Well, after Obama had taken office
it was discovered that the person,

425
00:22:32.340 --> 00:22:37.770
the photographer who created that work
had used it from an AP photograph.

426
00:22:37.770 --> 00:22:39.450
An Associated Press photograph.

427
00:22:39.450 --> 00:22:42.290
He had taken the photograph,
and he'd gone into illustrator,

428
00:22:42.290 --> 00:22:46.060
and he vectorized the image, and
then he created that whole scheme.

429
00:22:47.700 --> 00:22:51.960
He was sued by the Associated Press for
millions of dollars and lost.

430
00:22:51.960 --> 00:22:54.110
Now granted, yes,
I said millions of dollars.

431
00:22:54.110 --> 00:22:57.700
That means he made millions
of dollars off of the image.

432
00:22:57.700 --> 00:23:01.080
So this is why they were able to get
millions of dollars back from him.

433
00:23:01.080 --> 00:23:04.100
So, I think the settlement was
something like 7 to $11 million or

434
00:23:04.100 --> 00:23:05.290
something like that.

435
00:23:05.290 --> 00:23:06.330
But the point here is,

436
00:23:06.330 --> 00:23:11.200
is he had created the work off of
a photograph taken by an Associated Press

437
00:23:11.200 --> 00:23:15.720
photographer, and that photographer
was the copyright holder of the work.

438
00:23:15.720 --> 00:23:18.700
This gentleman did not ask for permission.

439
00:23:18.700 --> 00:23:24.830
And derived his work from that photograph
and therefore he was liable for damages.

440
00:23:24.830 --> 00:23:29.270
And the court discovered that and
he was charged appropriately.

441
00:23:29.270 --> 00:23:32.840
So a derivative work comes from a work
that somebody else has created and

442
00:23:32.840 --> 00:23:34.290
you are using it in your work.

443
00:23:35.910 --> 00:23:36.820
Duration.

444
00:23:36.820 --> 00:23:38.658
Duration is how long
the copyright is good for.

445
00:23:38.658 --> 00:23:44.617
Now this one is kind of an interesting
story because the duration of a copyright

446
00:23:44.617 --> 00:23:50.306
is held by the copyright holder for
the lifetime of the copyright holder and

447
00:23:50.306 --> 00:23:54.842
50 to 70 years after the death
of the copyright holder.

448
00:23:54.842 --> 00:23:58.740
And this comes because of Mickey Mouse.

449
00:24:00.140 --> 00:24:05.260
When Walt Disney was starting out as
a designer, as a creator, an artist,

450
00:24:05.260 --> 00:24:09.750
he had created a character
that was a rabbit.

451
00:24:10.940 --> 00:24:15.340
And he had gone to New York, and
he was trying to get it syndicated and

452
00:24:15.340 --> 00:24:17.199
he was trying to work
with publishing houses.

453
00:24:18.220 --> 00:24:21.850
And he didn't sign the proper contracts,
and

454
00:24:21.850 --> 00:24:26.170
when he quit that job,
he couldn't take his work with him.

455
00:24:26.170 --> 00:24:29.610
They owned the right to that rabbit, okay?

456
00:24:29.610 --> 00:24:33.830
Well, when he created Mickey Mouse,
he was smart enough where he said,

457
00:24:33.830 --> 00:24:36.950
look, I need to get something in
writing here, I need to get laws made.

458
00:24:36.950 --> 00:24:38.590
I need something to help me out here.

459
00:24:38.590 --> 00:24:41.810
So he went to whoever he needed to go to,
and said,

460
00:24:41.810 --> 00:24:44.260
look I created this work, and
I don't want anyone else to use it.

461
00:24:44.260 --> 00:24:48.470
Well, what happened was,
the copyrights used to expire after so

462
00:24:48.470 --> 00:24:52.810
many years, and he went to Congress and
said, look, this expiring thing,

463
00:24:52.810 --> 00:24:56.000
you're going to make me loose billions of
dollars because literally Disney makes

464
00:24:56.000 --> 00:24:56.840
billions of dollars.

465
00:24:56.840 --> 00:24:59.100
One billion dollars a year
just on Mickey Mouse.

466
00:24:59.100 --> 00:25:01.990
And you would think that's kind of
crazy because Mickey Mouse is what

467
00:25:01.990 --> 00:25:02.950
60, 70 years old?

468
00:25:02.950 --> 00:25:03.630
It's very old.

469
00:25:03.630 --> 00:25:04.890
It's been around for a long time, but

470
00:25:04.890 --> 00:25:07.060
he still makes a billion dollars
a year just on Mickey Mouse.

471
00:25:07.060 --> 00:25:12.380
So, the point here is, to protect that
he goes, or the Walt Disney company

472
00:25:12.380 --> 00:25:17.440
continues to go to the Congress,and they
continue to solicit to extend this out.

473
00:25:17.440 --> 00:25:19.190
So we say 50 to 70 years,

474
00:25:19.190 --> 00:25:23.610
because I think the last time I heard
that congress was going to extend it.

475
00:25:23.610 --> 00:25:25.600
It was gonna be 70 years
after the person died.

476
00:25:25.600 --> 00:25:28.440
That's because Walt Disney
has been dead for awhile, and

477
00:25:28.440 --> 00:25:32.182
they don't want Micky Mouse's
copyright to lapse while he's dead.

478
00:25:32.182 --> 00:25:32.940
Because again, like I said,

479
00:25:32.940 --> 00:25:35.700
they still make a billions dollars
a year just on Micky Mouse.

480
00:25:35.700 --> 00:25:40.220
So the duration is 50 to 70 years
after the life of the person.

481
00:25:40.220 --> 00:25:41.830
Now there's some loopholes
in there as well.

482
00:25:43.400 --> 00:25:47.150
As the copyright holder, I can create
a foundation, I can create a group,

483
00:25:47.150 --> 00:25:50.670
an organization that
can my manage my work.

484
00:25:50.670 --> 00:25:52.610
And I can sign those rights over to them.

485
00:25:52.610 --> 00:25:54.800
And organizations never die.

486
00:25:54.800 --> 00:25:57.660
As long as there's somebody
there to run it, they never die.

487
00:25:57.660 --> 00:25:59.740
So that's one loophole around that,

488
00:25:59.740 --> 00:26:03.230
is to make sure that you've assigned
those rights to that organization.

489
00:26:03.230 --> 00:26:06.210
And organizations will never die,
as long as somebody's there to run it.

490
00:26:07.590 --> 00:26:08.810
Fair use.

491
00:26:08.810 --> 00:26:13.520
The term fair use comes from the fact that
as an educational facility, as people who

492
00:26:13.520 --> 00:26:19.350
work in academia, you can use works of
art that were created by somebody else.

493
00:26:19.350 --> 00:26:25.270
However, in academia you must cite
the original copyright holder.

494
00:26:25.270 --> 00:26:29.550
You must say, this came from the source
of whatever and do whatever else.

495
00:26:29.550 --> 00:26:34.130
You don't have to ask for permission, but
you should cite where the work came from.

496
00:26:35.610 --> 00:26:39.650
You can also create documentaries and
not have to worry about copyright.

497
00:26:39.650 --> 00:26:40.390
So, for example,

498
00:26:40.390 --> 00:26:45.300
when you watch the news and they're
standing in front of Enron, for example,

499
00:26:45.300 --> 00:26:48.820
back in the day, or I'll do one new today,
they're standing in front of Google.

500
00:26:48.820 --> 00:26:52.320
And they're taking a video and
they show you the Google logo.

501
00:26:52.320 --> 00:26:55.990
Well, normally Google owns the logo,
they own that whole thing,

502
00:26:55.990 --> 00:26:57.350
it's their copyright.

503
00:26:57.350 --> 00:27:02.120
But because it's a news organization doing
a documentary style thing, it's fair use.

504
00:27:02.120 --> 00:27:07.410
They can show the logo and
not have to pay royalties to Google.

505
00:27:07.410 --> 00:27:13.100
Now another thing is,
to talk about fair use, happy birthday.

506
00:27:13.100 --> 00:27:17.300
You know when you go into a restaurant and
it's somebody's birthday, and

507
00:27:17.300 --> 00:27:20.520
you let the waiter or the waitress
know that it's somebody's birthday.

508
00:27:20.520 --> 00:27:23.410
And you make sure there's a cake
available and everything, and

509
00:27:23.410 --> 00:27:25.806
then they get everybody together
when it's It's time for dessert.

510
00:27:25.806 --> 00:27:27.520
And they say, they'd come out and

511
00:27:27.520 --> 00:27:30.960
they'd start singing so
we hear it's your birthday da da na,

512
00:27:30.960 --> 00:27:33.090
and they'd start singing some other song,
not happy birthday.

513
00:27:33.090 --> 00:27:35.270
And you're like,
why aren't they singing happy birthday?

514
00:27:35.270 --> 00:27:38.780
Well, that's because AOL owned
the happy birthday tune,

515
00:27:38.780 --> 00:27:40.360
they have the copyright on it.

516
00:27:40.360 --> 00:27:42.700
And they made, I think it was,

517
00:27:42.700 --> 00:27:46.690
several million dollars a year on
the Happy Birthday tune every year.

518
00:27:46.690 --> 00:27:51.450
And it would cost you $2500 to sing
the song in public every time you did it,

519
00:27:51.450 --> 00:27:53.780
especially for
an organization like a restaurant.

520
00:27:53.780 --> 00:27:55.340
So you couldn't do that.

521
00:27:55.340 --> 00:28:00.000
Luckily, just recently,
I think as recent as last year,

522
00:28:00.000 --> 00:28:07.390
Happy Birthday was
placed in public domain.

523
00:28:07.390 --> 00:28:12.330
So now anybody can sing happy birthday
regardless of not having to pay the $2500

524
00:28:12.330 --> 00:28:13.320
license fee for it.

525
00:28:13.320 --> 00:28:15.977
So happy birthday is now in public domain.

526
00:28:15.977 --> 00:28:21.500
So fair use is when you use
something to teach others or

527
00:28:21.500 --> 00:28:23.890
when you use it in a documentary.

528
00:28:23.890 --> 00:28:27.160
However I've seen people
on YouTube claim fair

529
00:28:27.160 --> 00:28:32.180
use when they're using content from music
or whatever it is on the internet and

530
00:28:32.180 --> 00:28:37.730
they've created a video and they cut
it off at the last maybe 30 seconds.

531
00:28:37.730 --> 00:28:39.660
They're kind of sawing
off the last 30 seconds.

532
00:28:39.660 --> 00:28:43.260
Then they claim fair use because they
didn't use the entire work, okay?

533
00:28:43.260 --> 00:28:46.420
Well they used the derivative work and
that's an infringement.

534
00:28:46.420 --> 00:28:47.370
So that's something to keep in mind.

535
00:28:48.440 --> 00:28:52.490
Infringement is when you violate
the Digital Millennium Copyright Act.

536
00:28:52.490 --> 00:28:57.540
Whenever you receive that movie on that
CD that you got from a friend because

537
00:28:57.540 --> 00:29:01.470
they downloaded it off the internet, you
are infringing on somebody's copyright.

538
00:29:01.470 --> 00:29:03.750
Whenever you take that
picture off the Internet,

539
00:29:03.750 --> 00:29:07.980
you find it in Google you take it off,
and you print it on to a CD cover and

540
00:29:07.980 --> 00:29:11.100
you sell that to somebody, you've
just infringed on somebody's rights.

541
00:29:11.100 --> 00:29:12.590
Now granted, if you download an image and

542
00:29:12.590 --> 00:29:17.430
you put it on the backdrop of your
computer That's not infringement per se.

543
00:29:17.430 --> 00:29:21.920
You are not publicly putting it
out there for people to see.

544
00:29:21.920 --> 00:29:25.110
We are talking about when you publicly
put it out there for people to see, so

545
00:29:25.110 --> 00:29:28.470
when you design your webpages,
and whatever content you use,

546
00:29:28.470 --> 00:29:30.190
you better have paid for that content.

547
00:29:30.190 --> 00:29:31.950
And, you better understand
the licensing for that.

548
00:29:31.950 --> 00:29:34.620
Otherwise, you might be infringing
on somebody's copyright.

549
00:29:34.620 --> 00:29:40.300
Now, there are websites,
like Shutterstock, and things like that,

550
00:29:40.300 --> 00:29:46.460
Dreamstime, where you can purchase the
rights to put these elements on your page.

551
00:29:46.460 --> 00:29:50.590
And these are stock photos of just people
doing poses and that kind of thing.

552
00:29:50.590 --> 00:29:55.300
Or sports athletes with no branding for
logos or anything on their clothing.

553
00:29:55.300 --> 00:29:58.120
But they're kicking around a soccer
ball or throwing a football.

554
00:29:58.120 --> 00:29:59.350
Those are things you can purchase.

555
00:29:59.350 --> 00:30:02.770
And it's usually $.50 to
$1.00 to purchase that.

556
00:30:02.770 --> 00:30:07.020
But at that point, you are now purchasing
the rights to put them up on your webpage

557
00:30:07.020 --> 00:30:09.280
and you don't have to cite that
you got it from Shutterstock or

558
00:30:09.280 --> 00:30:11.240
you got it from Dreamstime,
you don't have to cite.

559
00:30:13.160 --> 00:30:18.020
Lastly, the term intellectual property
is anything that's created by you

560
00:30:18.020 --> 00:30:22.210
that is considered to be
a copyrightable work, okay.

561
00:30:22.210 --> 00:30:24.370
Intellectual property is
something that you create,

562
00:30:24.370 --> 00:30:29.180
you've thought about it, you've used
your mind to devise it in some way and

563
00:30:29.180 --> 00:30:32.330
now you're putting it out there for
the world to see.

564
00:30:32.330 --> 00:30:34.270
The minute you publish it out to the web,

565
00:30:34.270 --> 00:30:37.730
it's technically protected by
the Digital Millennium Copyrights Act.

566
00:30:37.730 --> 00:30:39.305
It used to be you had to apply.

567
00:30:39.305 --> 00:30:43.070
You had to go to a congressional office or
something and

568
00:30:43.070 --> 00:30:46.770
you would apply to a government office
to make sure you had the copyrights.

569
00:30:46.770 --> 00:30:49.700
But now because of the way everything
works in the digital world, the minute

570
00:30:49.700 --> 00:30:54.290
you publish it out there and you include
certain terminology on your website,

571
00:30:54.290 --> 00:30:58.010
you now own the content of that website.

572
00:30:58.010 --> 00:30:59.680
And we're gonna talk about
that here in a minute.

573
00:30:59.680 --> 00:31:01.490
So, intellectual property.

574
00:31:01.490 --> 00:31:05.580
Also, I've had questions from people,
because I teach Illustrator and

575
00:31:05.580 --> 00:31:07.700
I teach applications that
let me create content.

576
00:31:09.040 --> 00:31:14.020
And people ask me, well if If I
created this app while I was at work,

577
00:31:14.020 --> 00:31:16.760
I still own the app because it
had nothing to do with my job.

578
00:31:18.180 --> 00:31:19.510
No!

579
00:31:19.510 --> 00:31:23.020
Anything you do while you're on the clock
at your work is owned by your company,

580
00:31:23.020 --> 00:31:25.680
and you need to Need to keep that in mind.

581
00:31:25.680 --> 00:31:30.360
Unless it's specified in the contract
that you can do these things and

582
00:31:30.360 --> 00:31:33.530
they won't be the copyright
holder everything you do at work.

583
00:31:33.530 --> 00:31:38.530
And so including creating content for
websites for your company They own it.

584
00:31:38.530 --> 00:31:41.270
Including creating a logo or
creating whatever.

585
00:31:41.270 --> 00:31:42.660
They own that content.

586
00:31:42.660 --> 00:31:46.130
It's not untill you either get that
in writing in your contract or

587
00:31:46.130 --> 00:31:48.490
you leave and don't do the work.

588
00:31:48.490 --> 00:31:52.350
The best thing just to do at home Don't
do any of this stuff at work, and

589
00:31:52.350 --> 00:31:52.920
you'll be fine.

590
00:31:52.920 --> 00:31:55.460
Because you then own
the intellectual property.

591
00:31:56.580 --> 00:31:59.610
Okay, the last piece I wanna talk
about with regards to copyright

592
00:31:59.610 --> 00:32:02.300
is literally what you need to declare

593
00:32:02.300 --> 00:32:06.360
that you are the copyright holder
of the intellectual property.

594
00:32:06.360 --> 00:32:08.910
The first thing you need
is the word copyright

595
00:32:08.910 --> 00:32:10.380
Needs to be somewhere on your page.

596
00:32:10.380 --> 00:32:12.940
Usually I include it at the bottom
of every single one of my pages.

597
00:32:12.940 --> 00:32:14.570
And you've seen this before on websites.

598
00:32:14.570 --> 00:32:17.960
Right at the bottom it says copyright,
and then it has the copyright symbol and

599
00:32:17.960 --> 00:32:22.740
the year 2016, 2015,
whatever the copyright year is.

600
00:32:22.740 --> 00:32:24.550
Then it has to have
the copyright holders name,

601
00:32:24.550 --> 00:32:26.990
and then all rights reserved after it.

602
00:32:26.990 --> 00:32:30.000
So I've given you a sample
down here at the bottom,

603
00:32:30.000 --> 00:32:33.480
copyright 2016,
Jymbeau.com all rights reserved.

604
00:32:33.480 --> 00:32:38.170
So basically this is a correct
way to write a copyright and

605
00:32:38.170 --> 00:32:41.330
this lets everybody know that you own
the rights, to everything on your site.

606
00:32:43.930 --> 00:32:48.990
Okay, so
that is in a nutshell our discussion about

607
00:32:50.640 --> 00:32:54.390
the design,
principles of web design and copyright.

608
00:32:54.390 --> 00:32:58.570
>> Well Jim I appreciate that and I'm sure
you appreciate that out there, you might

609
00:32:58.570 --> 00:33:01.800
have just saved us quite a bit of money
>> If we would've violated

610
00:33:01.800 --> 00:33:05.170
any of those laws, or maybe not understood
that right so I do appreciate that.

611
00:33:05.170 --> 00:33:08.210
It does look like we're gonna sign off for
this episode, but before we do Jim,

612
00:33:08.210 --> 00:33:10.070
do got any parting advice?

613
00:33:10.070 --> 00:33:14.530
>> Again just keep in mind that if you've
created the content, from scratch,

614
00:33:14.530 --> 00:33:16.620
you own it and you're protected.

615
00:33:16.620 --> 00:33:20.630
If you are pulling it down from the web,
and you didn't ask for permission,

616
00:33:20.630 --> 00:33:25.560
you don't own it And that's really
the easiest way to consider copyright.

617
00:33:25.560 --> 00:33:27.900
If you created it from your own tools,

618
00:33:27.900 --> 00:33:30.590
from your own thought process,
you're good to go.

619
00:33:30.590 --> 00:33:33.380
If you pull it from the Internet and
then you derive something out of it, or

620
00:33:33.380 --> 00:33:35.920
you use a piece of it to
something else you're doing,

621
00:33:35.920 --> 00:33:37.540
you're infringing on
somebody else's right.

622
00:33:37.540 --> 00:33:39.550
And you can ask for permission.

623
00:33:39.550 --> 00:33:44.570
>> I've been a web developer for
many sites, people have written to me and

624
00:33:44.570 --> 00:33:48.560
emailed me and have said,
Jim is this, can I use this?

625
00:33:48.560 --> 00:33:51.090
I work for a school, and
I say fair use, no problem.

626
00:33:51.090 --> 00:33:53.190
School's good,
other things Things that I'll say, yeah,

627
00:33:53.190 --> 00:33:55.990
just site me, site me back,
and they're fine.

628
00:33:55.990 --> 00:33:57.010
So keep that in mind.

629
00:33:57.010 --> 00:33:57.600
>> Very good.

630
00:33:57.600 --> 00:33:58.910
We appreciate that information.

631
00:33:58.910 --> 00:34:00.530
We appreciate you the viewer out here.

632
00:34:00.530 --> 00:34:03.930
Signing out for ITProTV,
I've been your host Wes Bryan.

633
00:34:03.930 --> 00:34:04.790
>> And I'm Jim Sirrels.

634
00:34:04.790 --> 00:34:06.693
>> And we'll see you next time.

635
00:34:06.693 --> 00:34:15.110
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Jim demonstrate how to push the website into production by publishing it. They look at some of the tools that can be used to validate the website, perform link checking and spelling checker.
episodes.title: Publishing Your Site
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.722 --> 00:00:14.749
Welcome back to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.749 --> 00:00:16.262
I'm your host Wes Bryan, and

4
00:00:16.262 --> 00:00:20.090
in today's episode we are moving
through our series in DreamWeaver.

5
00:00:20.090 --> 00:00:22.640
That's right, we're coming back
with some more creative Cloud 2015,

6
00:00:22.640 --> 00:00:26.060
and we're going to be looking
at publishing your site.

7
00:00:26.060 --> 00:00:28.350
Joining me back in the studios
today is none other than Mr.

8
00:00:28.350 --> 00:00:30.510
Jim Serros, Jim, how you doing today, sir?

9
00:00:30.510 --> 00:00:32.710
>> I'm doing great Wes,
thank you for having me back, and

10
00:00:32.710 --> 00:00:34.340
thank you to the ITProTV team for

11
00:00:34.340 --> 00:00:37.470
having me here as well to discuss
DreamWeaver And specifically,

12
00:00:37.470 --> 00:00:41.560
we're going to be talking about
publishing our design out to the web.

13
00:00:41.560 --> 00:00:44.200
And I'd like to kind of finish
up some content here and

14
00:00:44.200 --> 00:00:49.120
talk about bringing in some
text from Microsoft Word, and

15
00:00:49.120 --> 00:00:54.400
then I'd like to show you the server
space within our sites panel

16
00:00:54.400 --> 00:00:57.240
which will allow us to add our FTP.

17
00:00:57.240 --> 00:01:01.030
And if some of the terminology there
just got you confused or blew your mind,

18
00:01:01.030 --> 00:01:03.800
just be aware we're gonna talk about
those concepts and explain them to you so

19
00:01:03.800 --> 00:01:05.000
you understand what they are.

20
00:01:05.000 --> 00:01:08.140
So I'd like to dive back into my design
that we've been working on throughout

21
00:01:08.140 --> 00:01:09.780
this whole process.

22
00:01:09.780 --> 00:01:11.690
And I'd like to go into
the main section here.

23
00:01:11.690 --> 00:01:14.630
Now, you've seen before where we
could type whatever text we want.

24
00:01:14.630 --> 00:01:17.740
But I'd like to import text
from a Word document just so

25
00:01:17.740 --> 00:01:20.210
I have a more completed homepage here.

26
00:01:20.210 --> 00:01:22.739
So I'm gonna erase the word home.

27
00:01:22.739 --> 00:01:26.870
And then I am gonna go up to the file
menu, and I am gonna choose Import.

28
00:01:26.870 --> 00:01:30.120
I can literally import
data into my document.

29
00:01:30.120 --> 00:01:33.230
So if I choose Import,
I can do XML into template.

30
00:01:33.230 --> 00:01:36.730
XML is extensible markup language,
basically it's

31
00:01:36.730 --> 00:01:41.530
part of the family of markup languages
like HTML, hypertext markup language.

32
00:01:41.530 --> 00:01:44.510
And basically,
it just means that what's coming is data.

33
00:01:44.510 --> 00:01:45.440
Tabular data,

34
00:01:45.440 --> 00:01:48.190
basically what we talked about in
a previous episode regarding tables.

35
00:01:48.190 --> 00:01:51.040
You can organize your
information as tabular data.

36
00:01:51.040 --> 00:01:53.880
But I can bring in a Word document or
even an Excel document.

37
00:01:53.880 --> 00:01:56.050
So, in this case I wanna
bring in some text so

38
00:01:56.050 --> 00:01:58.200
I'm gonna click on
the Word document option.

39
00:01:58.200 --> 00:02:00.870
When I do that,
it goes into my sites route and

40
00:02:00.870 --> 00:02:03.020
it says, here's a document from Word.

41
00:02:03.020 --> 00:02:06.290
Now, this is an older version of
Word as you can see cuz it does not

42
00:02:06.290 --> 00:02:08.580
have the x at the end.

43
00:02:08.580 --> 00:02:12.700
But I'm going to select that file,
and I'm going to click Open.

44
00:02:13.980 --> 00:02:16.690
Now some things I like to talk about
down here especially this one.

45
00:02:16.690 --> 00:02:19.330
It says Clean up Word paragraph spacing.

46
00:02:19.330 --> 00:02:22.580
What's gonna happen is it's going
to bring in some text structure and

47
00:02:22.580 --> 00:02:25.540
basic formatting from the Word document.

48
00:02:25.540 --> 00:02:28.730
If ever you've created a Word Document,
you might not have noticed this, but

49
00:02:28.730 --> 00:02:31.600
you can use headings,
you can use paragraphs,

50
00:02:31.600 --> 00:02:36.040
you can use a bunch of preset styles that
Word has set inside of the application.

51
00:02:36.040 --> 00:02:41.270
Well all of those will be translated by
html and understood as to what they are.

52
00:02:41.270 --> 00:02:44.770
But here it says Clean up Word paragraph
spacing, because whenever you hit

53
00:02:44.770 --> 00:02:48.340
the Enter key on the keyboard,
it adds spacing between all of your text.

54
00:02:48.340 --> 00:02:50.460
And here they're just saying
they're going to clean that up.

55
00:02:50.460 --> 00:02:52.220
So we'll see what happens
when we bring that in.

56
00:02:52.220 --> 00:02:55.120
Now we do want to grab this pulldown and
show you that I can change this.

57
00:02:55.120 --> 00:02:56.790
I can say, just bring in the text,

58
00:02:56.790 --> 00:03:00.180
don't bring in any formatting whatsoever,
I'll use cascading style sheets.

59
00:03:00.180 --> 00:03:01.320
Is to format it.

60
00:03:01.320 --> 00:03:04.710
You could say bring in the text structure,
paragraphs, lists and tables.

61
00:03:04.710 --> 00:03:07.730
You could say just bring in the basic
formatting which are bold and italic.

62
00:03:07.730 --> 00:03:10.900
Or you could say bring in the text
structure with the full formatting of

63
00:03:10.900 --> 00:03:13.280
bold, italic and
any styles that have been applied.

64
00:03:13.280 --> 00:03:15.640
And that would be your
paragraph styles for

65
00:03:15.640 --> 00:03:17.340
heading ones heading
to this kind of thing.

66
00:03:17.340 --> 00:03:20.500
So I'm just gonna do the bold and
italic here, the default setting.

67
00:03:20.500 --> 00:03:22.060
And I'm gonna click Open.

68
00:03:22.060 --> 00:03:26.660
And it should bring the text right
into my editable region, which it did.

69
00:03:26.660 --> 00:03:29.010
So now I have something
that I can test against.

70
00:03:29.010 --> 00:03:32.150
The first thing I'd like to do before
publishing is I wanna make sure that

71
00:03:32.150 --> 00:03:37.020
the text inside of my file
is at least spell checked.

72
00:03:37.020 --> 00:03:42.360
So Dreamweaver allows you to do that
by going up to the Commands menu and

73
00:03:42.360 --> 00:03:44.540
choosing the Check Spelling option.

74
00:03:44.540 --> 00:03:45.990
It's also Shift+F7 on your keyboard.

75
00:03:45.990 --> 00:03:50.530
Now it's gonna come up and say DreamWeaver
has reached the end of the document,

76
00:03:50.530 --> 00:03:51.520
you want to continue checking.

77
00:03:51.520 --> 00:03:53.900
Because my cursor was
at the end of the text,

78
00:03:53.900 --> 00:03:57.220
it wants to start over again from
the beginning, so I'm gonna say yes.

79
00:03:57.220 --> 00:04:02.390
And right now it is finding that there is
ample ampleness, I'm not sure where that

80
00:04:02.390 --> 00:04:09.150
word is, but I know that word doesn't make
any sense to me unless I can add it here.

81
00:04:09.150 --> 00:04:13.370
So I'm going to say change Online
it says it's one word, but

82
00:04:13.370 --> 00:04:14.420
it's putting a capital letter.

83
00:04:14.420 --> 00:04:17.440
I'll say change, again,
just spell checking, and there we go.

84
00:04:17.440 --> 00:04:20.910
So, now we went through,
it checks the text out, and

85
00:04:20.910 --> 00:04:23.750
I'm happy with the fact that it did the
spellchecking job that it was supposed to

86
00:04:23.750 --> 00:04:25.470
do, whether I agree with it or not.

87
00:04:25.470 --> 00:04:28.960
That's okay, but the machine
did what it was supposed to do.

88
00:04:28.960 --> 00:04:30.950
Now there's another check
that I'd like to do,

89
00:04:30.950 --> 00:04:35.010
I'd actually like to check for
any link errors that I might have, or

90
00:04:35.010 --> 00:04:37.890
some other checks that are available
to me within Dreamweaver.

91
00:04:37.890 --> 00:04:39.490
And this is all done before I publish.

92
00:04:39.490 --> 00:04:41.160
So, I'm ready to go.

93
00:04:41.160 --> 00:04:44.730
This particular item that I wanna bring
up is going to be in the window menu, so

94
00:04:44.730 --> 00:04:46.140
when I click on the window, and

95
00:04:46.140 --> 00:04:50.020
I go down to results, you have a whole
bunch of items you can work with.

96
00:04:50.020 --> 00:04:51.890
You can validate your code.

97
00:04:51.890 --> 00:04:53.010
You can do a line checker.

98
00:04:53.010 --> 00:04:55.730
You can look for site reports or FTP logs.

99
00:04:55.730 --> 00:05:00.480
Basically, looking at an FTP log will
tell you how many times you've tried to

100
00:05:00.480 --> 00:05:04.800
connect to your file transfer protocol
site and whether or not you had errors.

101
00:05:04.800 --> 00:05:08.050
A site report will tell you how many
sites you got, or how many pages

102
00:05:08.050 --> 00:05:11.690
you got within your site and
what the content is and things like that.

103
00:05:11.690 --> 00:05:14.880
The line check, the link checker sorry,
will check your hyperlinks to make

104
00:05:14.880 --> 00:05:17.400
sure that they do resolve
the way they're supposed to and

105
00:05:17.400 --> 00:05:20.310
validation will test my code,
my html 5 code and

106
00:05:20.310 --> 00:05:24.590
my CSS3 code against the standard
that is out there on the web So

107
00:05:24.590 --> 00:05:30.380
if I choose Link Checker in this example,
it's gonna bring up this dialog box.

108
00:05:30.380 --> 00:05:33.590
Now it's not really gonna do
anything until I hit this

109
00:05:33.590 --> 00:05:35.060
little Play icon here on the left.

110
00:05:35.060 --> 00:05:36.590
This is where you go to check.

111
00:05:36.590 --> 00:05:40.290
So I hit this Play icon, and I could tell
it to check the links in this current

112
00:05:40.290 --> 00:05:43.910
document, I could check the links for
the entire current local site, Or

113
00:05:43.910 --> 00:05:47.240
I could check for links for
selected files within the site.

114
00:05:47.240 --> 00:05:50.890
So, if I wanted to do the entire site,
I could choose this current local site and

115
00:05:50.890 --> 00:05:51.460
go from there but

116
00:05:51.460 --> 00:05:55.850
I just want to do this current document
for the sake of this conversation.

117
00:05:55.850 --> 00:05:59.490
So when I do that I see that I've
had no broken links whatsoever.

118
00:05:59.490 --> 00:06:03.820
So no link or files were found on
the local Discs that were broken.

119
00:06:03.820 --> 00:06:06.820
If I had anything that was broken
you would see in this list and

120
00:06:06.820 --> 00:06:09.820
you could double-click on it and it would
take you right into the code or right

121
00:06:09.820 --> 00:06:14.440
under a webpage where that link resides
and you could correct it at that time.

122
00:06:14.440 --> 00:06:17.290
Now in the status bar at the bottom
I am given some statistics,

123
00:06:17.290 --> 00:06:20.140
it's telling me that I've got one file,
one HTML.

124
00:06:20.140 --> 00:06:23.600
I've got 22 Links, and all 22 are okay.

125
00:06:23.600 --> 00:06:25.430
If I had any broken or any were external,

126
00:06:25.430 --> 00:06:27.680
it would tell me that here
as well in the bottom.

127
00:06:27.680 --> 00:06:30.620
So these items are down here,
